TL;DR at the bottom  This game follows the DBZ storyline, but with a twist. A distortion in time has occured, and you must be the one to stop it. You will be summoned by Trunks, and the story revolves around your custom-made character. I have seen many comments on the combat, and how it seems shallow. I don't really agree with this, though, as I found the combat to be rather fun. You can choose to button-smash, but if you have skills and timing, you can get a long way. A controller is highly advised though, as it makes everything easier.  PROS: - Interesting story - Lots of skills and clothes - RPG-elements - You don't have to purchase the DLC, but it's a nice addition. - Custom characters (!!) - Parallel quests - Masters you can train under (Frieza, #18, Cell and many more!) - Multiplayer is fairly stable now - Collecting Dragon Balls can be grindy, but summoning Shenron and wishing, definitely makes it worthwhile ;)  CONS: - I highly recommend a controller. I had a hard time playing with keyboard & mouse. - Tokitoki city is pretty big, and you have to walk around to each seperate booth to get things going. - Lacks some characters (Zarbon, Dodoria, #16 and the likes) - The DLC doesn't add a whole lot, yet is expensive (25 euros for season pass) - I found the Great Apes to be a bit clunky, but I suppose it is understandable with those huge models. - You have to grind levels quite a lot - Combat is pretty simple, and I understand why passionate fighting-genre fans would find it shallow. I enjoy it, nonetheless.  TL;DR: If you are a fan of Dragon Ball, you will most likely enjoy this game (get a controller, though!)  If you are a fan of the fighting genre, and want in-depth combat, you should probably look elsewhere.

This is one of those games based off an anime that's actually  good . I was worried at first I admit, but the people behind Dragon Ball: XENOVERSE put a lot of care into this game and I haven't even completed all of it yet! But I have played enough to understand and get a grasp of things.    Pros:      You get to create a character of your own based off the DBZ races ... even Buus!    Character creation holds a lot of variety, even though some sections are limited.    Most if not all cutscenes show your character in them, executed with swell animation.    Fighting mechanics are well done, action packed and gives you that rush per battle.    Able to customize your skills with almost any ki / martial art that exists in the DBZ universe.    Side quests aren't annoying and reward you with loot that's worth working for.    Co-op is extremely awesome in this game, and can make quests way funner.    Boss battles are fair, challenging but fair ... also difficulty doesn't change if you bring friends along.    The mini map is simple and very helpful in finding what section holds what.    Dialogue isn't cheesy and sometimes the actors will cuss, satisfying those who like that.    You're allowed to have 4 pages of taunts, which your character + other people's can do for fun.    Your character's build can go however you want them to be, either powerful in melee, ki blasts, or other.    Able to join the villains in their optional quests to take down the heroes.    There are trainers in which will teach you very useful abilities, along with sometimes aiding you in matches.    Able to customize your character with clothing / armor you've unlocked and most can have their color changed.    Extremely addicting game with a ton of replayability and benefits for which race you go as every time.    Easy to make friends in this game because of how important each player is during a mission.    NPCs will start to respect you the more you level up, sometimes even wanting to be trained under you.    Main campaign is interesting, villains are cool and yes you can eventually obtain their armor.    Able to play as any DBZ character you unlocked outside of your created character during any side quest.    Some cutscenes are animated that match the show, while the voice acting is well done since most dubs suffer.     Cons:      NPCs in PvP is somewhat unbalanced, while custom characters in PvP is absolutely broken. Some characters can one shot you with 3 bars of ki off the bat, while others have abilities that they can spam and stun lock you for ages. Most of the PvP also consists of hackers & cheaters, leaving people avoiding PvP altogether which is a shame.    Sometimes, even doing a quest / mission flawlessly will leave you with a C ranking simply becasue you didn't trigger the optional random event. These events happen at random, which is usually out of the player's control.    For very good loot, you sometimes have to grind for awhile. Performance doesn't trigger a better chance of obtaining loot.    If you're playing with three people, sometimes they can hog the enemy which leaves you having to race in landing a hit. This is especially true if you need to melee enemies to gather ki.    Certain abilities that you can get early outmatch the late game ones by a landslide, making the game too easy.    During certain parts of the mission, you will be given horde rush of enemies leaving you either bored or hurting.    If your partner is down and you need to revive them, it's likely you will be unable to because it takes awhile to fully revive them while the enemy is constantly beating on you.    There's no feature to see how clothes / armor will look on you when shopping... so it's only when you have obtained the equipment are you allowed to see how it'll look.    Certain enemies will transform in a cutscene, even while you're doing a combo or using a special attacking, meaning you've wasted that because the cutscene kicked in.    Certain side quests are brutally harder than 7 stars, despite they're only 4-6 stars. Some 7 stars are laughably easy.    Cannot change or alter your stats without having to make a whole new character.    Most armor / clothing until late game is useless for stat benefits. Some even harm you by going negative on an important section, hindering you despite wanting to wear it for fashion purposes.    You can fail a mission because an NPC died on yah, despite you've done everything to ensure survival.    Takes a long while at first to earn XP or zin (money) unless a friend is willing to let you ride with em on very difficult levels for the benefits of getting easy XP and zin without earning it.    Hard to understand the mechanics since the game doesn't do a good job explaining things. Only experience and playing will help you understand what does what exactly.    Lips don't move while characters are talking sometimes, breaking immersion.   All in all, this game is amazing though. The pros for certain, outweigh the cons and I adore what we've been given here. This is a game that DBZ fans will love for months while non fans shall still enjoy the daylights out of this game. You want to be a Sayian who looks like you, but can still go Super Sayian and do all the things you've seen in the show? You can! Want to be Freiza's race and wreck everything with death beams or super spirit bombs with one hand? You can! Want to have a female Buu who's super adorable but can kick the crap out of Broly hand-to-hand?? You can! This game lets you have that, and I appreciate it. I especially love seeing my custom character in the cutscenes being vital to the story. Not to mention this game is only $49.99 right now on Steam and will definitely go on price during Steam Sales. Worth full price in my eyes.

Story  Pros  Cons    Main Story  Experience the Dragon Ball Z sagas again as you fight to stop time manipulators from changing history for the worse  They cut alot of content from the adventures, and skipped alot of transformations for the villains    Side Story  You can fight on the side of good guys or bad in the parallel quests           Concept  Pros  Cons    Multiplayer  Up to 3 people can party together and fight   It could just be me, but the latency even with max bars seems utterly insane and makes chaining attacks nearly impossible especially as melee     Lobby  Allows you to run around and see what people are looking for objective or teammate wise   Having a custom chat would have been nice so I could be more direct with people    Character Creation  The character creation options you use like (race/weight/height) effect how your character can fight and has tradeoffs      Customization  There are several different (skills/transformations/equipment) you can equip to make your Z-warrior trounce other players or just the typical AI  I would perfer transformations for freezia race rather than custom looks     Hire System  People are able to use your characters for their adventures and you even get rewarded each time   The AI for your characters are generally horrendous making people more hesitant to even bother     Apprentice System  You can be the apprentice of many of the notable characters of DBZ ranging from Krilliin to goku himself  No easy way in-game to check what your suppose to do to move up in the ranks    DLC  Adds a couple more missions to play and characters to use, great challenge even for the upper level 80's           Gameplay  Pros  Cons    C-c-c-combo!  There is plenty of ways to combo off enemies even when you hit them back  Nearly impossible to do in online battles with others since the latency makes the enemies not register the hits or straight up teleport    Charging My Lazors  At times you will find online people or yourself charging up to unleash a barrage of specials, and you just have to fend off the enemies off till they are ready (sounding familiar)      Super Sayin  Is essentially a spam super moves until your blue in the face (inspired by vegeta no doubt)  Can't go super sayin 3 or higher that is main character perks apparently.

This is currently the most expensive game in my Steam library by far, costing me $94 (conversion rate, aka the Australia tax.... don't ask)  I don't regret it one bit. Very fun game, and I've had no server issues. It's faithful to the series, combat can become a bit repetitive but the extremely large range of attacks and collectables to earn give the game a lot of replay value. Fun in multiplayer too.  For those who are unsure about the character selection: you play as a custom character throughout the story mode, but every other mode gives you the option to play as the characters you know and love (such as Goku, Vegeta, Trunks, Gohan (Kid/Teen/Adult), Kril-I mean, Frieza, Cell etc.) and most characters have multiple setups that change their attacks, stats and appearance. For example, you can play as very early Saiyan saga Goku through to late Buu Saga Goku (base Kaioken to SSj3! +   Super Saiyan God Goku as a seperate character  ), and every appearance inbetween up to the recent movie.

First Dragon Ball game in PC, finally my 15 year old dream came true as a PC only gamer. Hype is very real. Will update my review as I keep playing the game.   Pro's       Dragon Ball Z in Steam :D    Refreshing new story mode with good gameplay mechanics.    Port is great and really good looking graphics.    Constant 60fps with silky smooth game play.    No FPS drops so far.    Custom character creator is good, of course more options would've been nice but still this is good.    Parallel quests system and side missions are a nice touch.    Con's       Screen tearing is there a little bit, fixable with enabling vsync ;)    Some music on cutscenes is bit bland sometimes, English voice acting too sadly.    Could use a better tutorial when it comes to blocking    Character roster is around 45 without dlc's, not a huge issue but some might miss their favorite character.     Stage damages and some stuff like that could've been better, I guess last gen consoles dragged back the title a little.   A must buy for any Dragon Ball Fan imho. Happy Dragon Ball hunting :tgrin:

First Dimps Dragon Ball game on PC, (thank god it isn't spike).   Excellent game, these are the guys responsible for the Budokai series along with Burst Limit, Infinite World and the PSP games. All fantastic games. Dimps always stuck to 2D style fighting but their foray in 3D style like Spike's Tenkaichi/Raging Blast is wonderful, leagues better than Spike's and on their first try to boot.  PC version wise, this is a fantastic running game.   I highly recommend this to anyone that has been playing the yearly releases of Dragon Ball games since the 90s.   Hopefully someone at Bamco decides to bring the Budokai HD collection to PC as well!  I'd also like to add, the first DLC is really underwhelming, but there is apparently more to come so that's a good start.   Also I'd like to address a few things. Avoid PVP for now, It's just a mess of bad connections and there are a (few) people who a trainer to edit their stats. So for the moment until everything is fixed don't expect a consistent online PVP experience.   Another thing, is meta. You can't avoid this with any online game. People will find and use the most broken things and all you can do is simply play around it or find out how to combat it. Dimps still has a little ways to go with patching so don't expect balance at the moment.  Also, why so little Nameks? Everyone is a Saiyan grill that just spams ki attacks? Where is the variety? If there is another game in the series the Create a Character can be more expanded upon to stop people from being so cookie cutter. Just my 2 cents.

Early Days server issues aside, This would have to be the most challenging and most satisfying Dragon Ball Z Fighting game to date.   PROS:  NO QTE's. PERIOD. NONE.  Solid Combat. Some of the moves and combos have little deadzones, but you don't need Street Fighter Reflexes to feel satisfied playing this. Create a Character is VERY rewarding, Even if you need to stack either Ki and Supers or Melee attacks. It's very Dragon Ball Z in that regard.  Storyline and Voice acting is Great. For myself, Very engaging.  Parallel Quests. This is a very fun and interesting take on setting up extra fights and it's a great time sink.  CONS:  Only Race with a transformation is Saiyan.  Item/Skill drops are VERY random and can get VERY frustrating grinding for one skill. Same goes for special events in PQ's.  Whis and Beerus smashing you into submission to the point where you basically lose the will to live. Yup, that fight sucks.    This is an amazing addition to the DBZ franchise. A beautifully crafted fighting game, with very little actual game engine flaws.  A MUST for and DBZ Game fan, and a MUST for any fighting game fan.   Needs offline mode, However, The Devs regularly update on the forums and through other sources, so it is clear they are aware and working on the issue. 2 Thumbs Up.  UPDATE: Server has been nice and stable for a while now. Can't say much about matchmaking, but at least the lobbies no longer kick you after every match.

As someone who is put off by anything related to anime due to it being something i've never really got into nor liked, I am rather happy to say I enjoyed this game even if you have limited knowledge of the franchise itself.  The story is basic yet engaging, to sum it up quickly, you'll play as a custom character of your choice (Human, Namekian, Majin, Saiyan or frieza's race) and have to help trunks, a saiyan from the franchise, by going back into past events of the dragon ball universe and fixing them. An example of this would be (Spoiler Spoiler Spoiler) Raditz at the start of the saiyan saga, instead of the usually weak raditz people know he's taken on a much stronger form and nobody knows why, you have to go and help goku and piccolo fight the now stronger raditz and make sure it ends in the way it did originally, with goku and raditz getting hit by piccolo's beam.   After story missions are completed, you slowly unlock side-missions relating to the story missions you did, an example of this would be to kill saibermen who were working with raditz, these give you experiance, mission rewards and a ranking from D-S (As far as I can tell)  Your character is fully customisable, with most of the moves used in dragon ball available, such as the famous Kamehameha and the galick gun and some more lesser used ones. When you gain enough experiance, you will level up and be able add points into your Ki amount, Health, Stamina amount, basic attack, super attack or super blast, which in turn makes the stat of it higher and boosts it. So it's very possible to make a character that uses a full close combat loadout and still have it as a viable tactic. On top of this, you can buy, find, or earn custom clothing in order to bost stats, such as Lord Slugs garb, or Turles's battlesuit, a wide range of clothing is available to suit your characters cosmetic and stat needs.  The combat itsef is very satisfying especially when you use your own custom character, it's very easy to pull off a combo even with limited understanding of the mechanics, whether it be shooting a kamehameha x10 or beating someone to a pulp in close range, it feels very responsive and fluid compared so some of the previous games (I'm talking about you, Battle of Z) The keyboard controlls are just as viable as using a gamepad, so people without one need not worry.   If I were to pick some negative aspects that push the game down for me, it would be the servers (Now mostly fixed) which disconnect you randomly, meaning you have to wait to log back in. And a lack of some of the movie characters and lack of character clothing, but it's still made up by what is available. Another problem i've found is that some special attacks are down right over or underpowered, the father and son kamehamea does the tiniest bit more damage than a normal one, while taking three Ki bars, while the blue swirl used by burter can deal nearly 3/4 damage of someones HP if they get in the whirlewind at the start, and this has a large AOE, so potentially you could destroy the whole team with one move.  Overall i'd give it a solid 7.5 out of 10, if it were to be pushed up to an 8 or a 9, the moves would have to be balanced out a bit more, and the servers would have to be working better, I would reccomend this to fans of the show who want a good game, but to those not into the game, it might be better to wait for some of the problems to be fixed, though I'd imagine they'd still have a lot of fun playing this.

If you liked the Dragon Ball, Dragon Ball: Z, and/or Dragon Ball: GT series', ESPECIALLY if you liked the gameplay of the Dragon Ball Z: Budokai Tenkaichi series and the Dragon Ball: Raging Blast series, I can already tell you that you will LOVE this game. While the gameplay does feel like a little bit of a simplification of the fast-paced, EXTREMELY skill-based combat of the Budokai Tenkaichi series, this is only because the game is more about RPG-based leveling and MMO interaction with other players. I guess what I'm trying to say is that the gameplay is shifted a bit away from skill and a bit more toward strategy. However, the BEAUTY of this game is how it's still extremely fun to play, with MUCH more emphasis put on supers, making the fights seem more action-packed by giving the players loads of ki from melee attacks. This kind of shorter battle makes the online play more bearable, as well.  The story of this game is just awesome. It's actually a totally unique story involving a new foe, who conveniently alters the timeline, requiring the players of the game to 'fix it' (i.e. fight various battles from the original DBZ timeline but with changes). For these fixes, you are first shown a cutscene of the situation the characters are facing, such as a gruesome scene with Piccolo firing the Special Beam Cannon, impaling Goku but......missing Raditz completely?! O NO! Yes some of it is a bit cheesy, but overall it's really fun, with tons of fully-animated cutscenes (FULLY LIP-SYNCED TO THE JAPANESE DUB, btw), as well as an AWESOME soundtrack, featuring synth-based orchestral pieces that sound like the original Japanese soundtrack and the Bruce Falconer soundtrack had a baby that was this game's soundtrack (ok that may be a bit of an exaggeration, but still it's great).   The thing that truly makes this game fun is getting to connect with friends and strangers alike and share your custom DBZ characters, playing VS matches online, and doing Parallel Quests online, allowing you to replay many parallel-timeline missions, which have various battle scenarios, some branching from the real timeline and others being completely changed ('what-if' saga, anyone?). Parallel Quests allow you to have fun with your friends (OR by yourself), while leveling up your character and giving you Zeni, allowing you to buy skills, consumables, clothing, and accessories from the game's vendors. You can replay a single quest as many times you like, as there are not only RNG-based loot drops but 'ultimate' finishes which you can attain by meeting various (unlisted) requirements for each mission, which are often simply absolutely reking the bejesus out of the mission and completely dominating the whole thing in a short amount of time.     So, with all that being said, if you liked the anime itself and the skill-based Budokai Tenkaichi and Raging Blast series' of DBZ games, you will probably have loads of fun with this game, likely playing it for hundreds of hours. However, if you don't have the extra elements of nostalgia as well as familiarity with the gameplay itself, this game does have its drawbacks, such as a lack of polish on a few of its parallel quests, and, especially with me coming from a background of playing lots of Demon's Souls and Dark Souls, not the most impressive amount of equipment, but still a huge amount. Additionally, if you are a person who dislikes games that make you earn your fun by being extremely difficult (such as Dark Souls), then you will likely dislike this game as well, because that's exactly what it is: really challenging but extremely awarding.  Even if you aren't a total diehard DBZ fan, taking the minor drawbacks into account and everything, you will likely still get a lot of enjoyment from this game, and for me to say that must really show a lot about how great this game is.   My final rating of the game: 9.5/10

I have played this game both on xbox 360 and PC with a total of over 100+ hours and can say it is an awesome game! The things you get in this game are cool and worth the you get many ways to customize your character such as skill points, clothing, race and gender. Story line is awesome because it is a little different from many of the previous Dragon Ball games and has a cool twist to the end. Parrelel quests are a good feature, it adds a whole lot more content to the game and cool drops so you can repeat the same quests waiting for a skill or a piece of clothing to drop. I also find that the fact you can change your characters skills into being an all melee type badass to a Kamehameha blasting maniac gives the game a lot of variation in terms of what you want your character to be, also choosing the right race with the right stats can give you a massive boost of power in battle.  I would say the things to improve on this game is more options for your character such as more hairstyles, I would like to have more hairstyles such as Raditz's and Vegeta's style, the ones we get for them are pretty lame as almost everyone in DBZ has a cool looking hairstyle and we get these Also a nerf on the character's skills would be nice as when I like to go pvp you get people maxing out everything into one stat and you get 1 combo'd with melee attacks or an ultimate skill which is not that fair or fun in my opinion.  Other than that this game is good if you are a dragon ball fan or even if you are not a fan pick it up and within a week you could be sat there watching the whole Dragon Ball series! This game could have been far greater than it actually is. I recommend to DBZ fans (as any hardcore fan can make it through any kind of related game), but as for players looking for a new detailed ground-breaking fighter, this simply isn't it. Get ready for a grind ladies and gents and get ready to break your X and Y buttons from repetitive mashing. In short, I like the game but it's hard to recommend for this price range.  It's well done, but if feels like it could have been done so much better. The general Toki Toki City area you get to 'freeroam' is slow paced at most, and for some reviewers, a shot in the dark and grind to do the next mission. I find simply moving about the level is a nuisance at most. Why not allow for flying? You have great characters and such a rich ability range to incorporate into the game, in and out of fighting! For something that could be so good, it's simply decent. Not only that, half the stations you go to are oddly 'closed' or unable to process your request. When they do work though, online parrallel universe fights with other players add some replayability to the game.  There are two basic modes to the game : freemode and fight mode. In free roaming mode, you essentially get to run around and either shop (for new skills, items, or clothing), talk, upgrade and change your personal stats, or choose between different game modes from either the story line or the online/offline parrallel universe modes (which are comparable to single matches). In fight mode, you get to do the juicy stuff like fly around and throw wild energy balls everywhere.  The story character creator is satisfactory, while the story itself is well integrated into the series. Maybe it's because I chose Namekian that I'm limited in options, it doesn't seem otherwise there is much to choose from in variety. Either way, the story line is a good addition to re-visiting old DB episodes. Gameplay itself isn't too shabby, but can sometimes seem all over the place. Flying is slightly choppy and isn't as smooth as it could be. The fighting seems nominal once you get how the teleportation and fighting system work, as well as the stamina. There is a lot of tutorials that slowly creep up on you, rush through them and it can be a rough play through. To me personally it seems at times random combo's and teleportation from side to side happen. In all honesty, I'd like to be in full control if I can dodge VIA teleporting or teleport to bounce the opponent to the other side of the map. The fighting has it's ups and downs, but when buttons start matching up to what your character is doing, there is a nice flow to what your watching in addition to being in control of. What was disappointing to me was there was no real feel of impact when you sent an opponent flying into the ground (there is an animation for it). Granted, there is some landscape that can be broken but it feels like crumping cardboard paper toghether, then it quickly unraveling back into perfect shape. The damage animations (not effects) are nice as breaking a tree with your opponents back but that permanent damage isn't there.   Visuals are nice and the custom character looks really good in cut-scenes. The fighting sounds seem on par, but addition of a few more sounds (especially collisions) would have enriched the auditory experience. What really drives me nuts is the music in the free roam. If being on repeat isn't bad enough, get ready to go nuts hearing the same song over and over. They have also incorporated built in phrases and actions the player can perform (such as waving or sitting). Credit definitely has to be given to the level creators as the places you can fight are all in the DB saga. Some locations you get to fight in are Kami's lookout, planet Namek, different places on Earth and even a stage outside of the Earth.  This game is good, but no where near worth it's stated price. I'm a huge DBZ fan and for what it's worth, I wish they gave a little more into the game. I like it because it's something I can relate to. Will you like it based on it's gaming aspect, or it's content? I have to give the game credit though for trying to give the player more than a story to play with. WIthin TokiToki city, you may run into a Ginyu force member or even Gohan asking you for help (with a sidequest). You can also ask different characters within game (like Vegeta or Piccolo in TokiToki city) to be your trainer. That voice will follow you to every debrief after every quest.  For future DBZ's give some freedom for the player to use the specials whenever, or at least have the choice to fly or walk in free roam. The incorporation of actions such as waving or squatting added a bit of depth to the open world. That I definitely liked and would like to see that again. Also, the attacks were well done (minus button mashing X and Y at times) but I feel there needs to be improvement for the vanishing system. Dodging consist of jumping in the air while doing a front flip, which is fine, but the actual trait of disappearing and ending up behind an enemy is the whole fun of the Dragon Ball universe! I'd like to be able to vanish half the map for half or more of my stamina, but the closer I am, let me jump around my enemy for a bit!  If this game was $15-20 I would recommend it, as of now though, no. To true Dragon Ball fans : I think you will enjoy the game and play a decent chunk of it. You may find the money's worth. Alright, so let's start with my first comment: BUY THIS GAME. It is absolutely fantastic and a vital piece of gaming media for a Dragon Ball fan. I didn't think I'd like it, then I played it and now it's one of my favourite online games. I can assure you, you will love it.  Now, let's get down to pros and cons.  PROS:   Easy to pick up gameplay, tricky to master but not exactly 'hard'.  A fun, engaging experience that will have your attention for hours on end.  A steady levelling system that has you work for it, but doesn't grind your face in the dirt or require you put in hours to get a single level.  Gameplay and advancement are well-paced and don't require too much effort, though you're not just handed everything either.  Nice simple graphics that don't tax an average rig too much even at full power; a good offset to the major problem of PC gaming.  Smooth, comfortable integration of USB controllers, although the keyboard controls are just as easy to learn.  ==  CONS:  Some ridiculously difficult Parallel Quest scenarios that will have you seething with rage as if you were playing Street Fighter or KOF.  Server can be a bit laggy and interfere with multiplayer experiences at times; I played with someone only a few miles away and we still had a tricky time with collision detection and movement lag.  Customization. It's another game that presents itself as being highly customizable in terms of character creation, however when you actually get down to it, it's pretty limited. You can only change colours on a very small selection of outfits; the others are based off outfits from the franchise, and as you would expect, they kill the 'character creation' function because the moment the average gamer is given a creativity toy, their first instinct is to make things they already know, so everyone thinks they're Goku, everyone thinks they're Gohan, etc. and very few people actually bother to make an original character in this.  It's a Namco Bandai game. They do this all the time; they bring out a great game that shows so much promise, only give it a little bit of content expansion and then abandon it to work on an inferior title, in this case that new One Piece thing. With SoulCalibur V, they did the same thing to work on TTT2 which was massively inferior. So while they make great products, they're a rather careless and irresponsible company that don't care much for their own products (although they're definitely no Konami or EA).  ==  SUGGESTIONS:  Needs more interactive environments, especially in the hub world.  They should put in at least quite a few more expansions that focus on character creation. Most specifically, let us colour any outfit and let Majin go barefoot; perhaps also some footwear like sandals or ankle guards. What we have is extremely limited despite being presented as bigger than it is.  An actual chatbox so players can talk to each other with text. I appreciate the effort to filter out spam by giving us preset messages, but come on - a private chat window at least.  I hate to sound like a feminazi, but there are SO many great female fighters in the Dragon Ball universe that you completely ignored. There are about a half dozen playable females in this game and several dozen males. Just look at the Dragon Ball Wikia and take your pick; you should put in at least 10 more females.

This review was written after the first gameplay session that lasted almost 15 hours. I was the last person among all my friends to have the game downloaded, yet i had the most played hours in just one day XD This game is absolutely the best DBZ game i've ever played in my life... but it has its cons, like low number of characters (but the amount of good characters and variations outweigh that).  Pros: - Best DBZ Game Graphics! Although graphics don't matter, this game captures the DBZ feeling so well! - Gameplay mechanics are easy-to-learn, hard-to-master For some reason, as i progressed through the game, i started using less complicated combos, but i should be practicing them in the future. - Create your own character Who doesn't wanna be a Z-warrior? and to top it off, you have 8 different variations of gender/race - A ♥♥♥♥TON OF REPLAYABILITY! The parallel quests are seemingly endless, and you'll find yourself replaying the same thing over and over again (still having fun with it) just to get that one skill or item...but you end up finding a hidden condition or something that rewards you with better stuff :D - All-new Story Without spoilers, i found the story really awesome (though it felt like a Time Squad rip-off xD), i loved the fact that there are 2 endings (if you defeat the final boss fast, before a certain somebody could come and aid you, you get the secret ending). - Deep interactions, like characters recognizing your CaC's race and commenting on such, or fun interactions like Vegeta SSJ4 with Beerus - A lot of other stuff like the Master System and such  Cons:  - Gathering the dragonballs is a pain in the butt, i still haven't gathered them all :\ - Some missions you'll be pitted against 2 or 3 super saiyans at the same time, and those mofos keep spamming their ultimate because of their seemingly infinite ki, it kinda gets annoying especially when you need to finish the quest for an item or such - There's a bunch of glitches that happen often, though they're not that major and i'm sure they'll be fixed - Some missing characters/transformations (although some could be understandable) - The whole DLC ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t...tbh i feel with those people who were waiting for reviews to see if they should get the game or not...and they had a low chance of guaranteeing a 'preorder' copy of the game on any platform... seriously? ssj4 vegeta for DLC when goku and gogeta ssj4 are in the game? and i found files for great ape baby in the game...that's supposed to be $10 DLC  Overall 9/10 Why? the game is way better than the whole PS3/X360 gen games, and possibly better than Budokai 3 and Tenkaichi 3. the downsides are just technical things that can be fixed, but the DLC thing is an issue (if anyone is familiar with the DLC ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that the game Evolve had, this is kind of the same thing). So, should you get the game? ♥♥♥♥ YES! would you enjoy the game? depends on your taste.   Hope you found my review helpful.

THIS is the Dragonball Z game that every kid wanted 13 years ago, flaws and all.   The fighting system can sometimes feel a bit cheap but there's no mistaking it: you can pull off insane combos just like you see on the show, and it's so fun when you do.  There's a lot (and i do mean a LOT) of player grinding. You are meant to do side missions, improving your time and ability each time you do them, for the experience, money, and item drops. You then use the money to buy better skills, or learn them from a trainer. If it sounds tedious it certainly can be, but the combat is what keeps the game from devolving into being boring. I really didn't mind that I was grinding because the combat was just THAT fun.   This goes without saying that your nostalgia and how much of a DBZ fan you are will have a huge impact on your ability to play this game. If you loved DBZ as a kid (or hell, even now!) and you always wanted to play a fighting system that let you do the crazy stuff you see, then this is the game for you. If you are looking for the next deep/technical fighter then look elsewhere.

Great game, I played the Budokai series when they were first released and those were my favorite DBZ games for the longest time, but it looks like this game could top those. The combat is easy to learn and very fun, but it will take time to master and you can tell who has more practice.   The game story mode has you create your own character (Saiyan, Earthling, Namekian, Frieza race, or Majin) and you help Trunks prevent the villians from changing the DBZ timeline. The main story from other games is there, but it is a new take on the story which lets you battle along the Z warriors with your own character.  The game also has a online or offline hub called Toki Toki City which can hold up to 200 players when online. You will be spending most of your time between missions here as you can shop for new gear and equipment for your character and start missions (offline / online: quests, story missions, versus mode, etc). There is no traditional chat system in the game, but there are many emotes (Wave) or messages (Hello, Good Bye, etc) you can use to interact with other players.  Overall the game is really enjoyable so far and I am looking forward to what will be added in the future with DLC.   Pros  + Combat very fun and fluid + Controls are great and easy to understand + Graphics are the best to date for a DBZ game + Create / customize your own Z warrior + Different take on story mode + PC port (up to 4k resolution, 60 FPS)   Cons  - Dialogue isn't the great - Some of the voices seem out of place at times (overall voices are good though) - No SSJ2 or SSJ3 for created saiyans, but I guess its understandable * Not much of a con, but many people are having issues with grinding XP to get through story mode. Sometimes the battles will be a lot harder than the last, so you will need to do side missions to level up before you can progress in story. (this allows you to make battles easier or more challenging, depending on how fast you level)   Port Quality  * Runs great so far with no issues * Various HD resolutions up to 4K  * Choose 30 or 60 FPS * Minor graphic options (AA, Shadows, Bloom, Vsync, few others)  If you are a fan of DBZ and fighting games I would definitely pick this game up. It is really fun and creating your own character and leveling up through battles is a great feature in this game.

Dragon Ball Xenoverse is a fun but flawed game. A must buy for all Dragon ball fans, but maybe not if you are not into the series.  STORY: The story focuses on your own created character. You can choose between a Saiyan, Earthling, Namekian, Majin or Friezas race. You are paired with Future Trunks to stop villains from destroying the timeline. You will fight battles from the Saiyan saga to Battle of Gods. The voice actors from Dragon Ball Kai all reprise their roles. Overall the story is plenty original and probably the best that can be done from a Dragon Ball game.   Gameplay: Unfortunatly gameplay is where this game struggles. While its always nice pulling off a Kamehameha or the distrcto disk. The actual combat itself is very shallow. Combos are down to when you stop pressing a light attack and start to heavy attack. Also if you go super saiyan you get unlimted ki attacks meaning you can literally break the game.   As this is an RPG you will have to complete side quests to reach a high enough level to continue the story. However there is also a massive grind to reach a level. (Unless you purchase the DLC when you get missions you can complete at a level you shouldnt be at. I managed to go up four levels in one mission because i played a DLC mission that was meant to be endgame but was too easy. There is also a master system where you can get charcters from the show to be your mentor. this can unlock new moves for your character. Yet the progression is way too slow. I went the whole story mode with only two mentors.   CONTENT:  At around fourty characeters, a story mode and a lot of side missions. DBX is certainly not lacking in that department. i have put in fifteen hours and have still only scratched the surface.    While it does have its flaws Dragon Ball Xenoverse certainly is a fun time. Maybe pick it up in a sale or wait for the sequel that is coming out near the end of this year.

So here are my honest thoughts on Dragonball Xenoverse. Note that I have played about 24 hours of the game, have yet to beat it (Although I am on the last set of missions) and still have not done all the parallel quests or master trainings.  I ♥♥♥♥ing love this game.  However, I am also a huge fan of the universe of Dragonball. And you really need to be a fan to get the most out of the game. The premise of the game is that you spend your time joining the 'Time Patrol' with Trunks in a place called TokiToki city, after he wishes for assistance from Shenron. Don't know who those are? Tough, its not explained. Again, you really need to be somewhat familiar with the universe of DBZ to get the most out of this.  YOu then spend your time doing Time Patrol missions which are basically you going back in time to correct 'errors' in the history of DBZ. You start by helping deal with Raditz, as somehow history was being changed to allow him to dodge the Special Beam Cannon attack, killing Goku but not him.  Again, if you have no idea what I am referring to, I can't help too much.  From there you uncover who is behind the strange time distortions. You also can do Parallel quests, which are basically side missions with alternate rules. In one you might help Frieza beat up the Z warriors. In another you might go and reenact the World Tournament against Yamcha, Tien, and Krillin.  You can also apprentice under various members of the DBZ Universe such as Piccolo, Vegeta, Gohan, Tien, Krillin, Android 18, Cell, Capt Ginyu, ect. You can thus learn their moves (Vegeta teaches Galick Gun and Final Flash for example, Ginyu teaches various fighting poses).  You also level up, raise your stats, and select your own combination of moves from the ones you have unlocked via PQs or Training.  And you will be grinding. A LOT. You can replay EVERY mission in the game, both story and PQ as many times as you want. And in order to level up to take on tougher challenges, and to get gear and moves, you need to grind PQs. I personally find the fighting fun so I do not mind so much. Collecting all the moves is a fun pastime for me.  Visually I love the art style, but I grew up on DBZ so it reminds me of happy times.  I can't speak too much on MP, as I have only been able to play in 1 single Multiplayer PQ without being kicked from the party (no idea why, maybe folks dont like Female Buus?). But it was fun to do, and the AI partners are no where near as smart as a player (Example: AI Goku with Super Saiyan on his moves list will NEVER BLOODY USE IT!)  Nothing makes me happier then punching Frieza in his smug Frieza face then hitting him with a Kamehameha followed by Milky Cannon. And maybe a Final Flash I dunno.  Be aware that some fights can feel cheap. Sometimes you gotta take on 2 fighters at the same time by yourself and they can easily ping pong you and wreck you. I cant beat PQ 32 because of this (stupid super saiyans and their stupid unlimited ultimate attacks)  So there ya go.  If you have ever dreamt of being a Z Fighter and helping to fight some of the big bads (I mean I got to face off with freaking MAJIN BUU!) then this is the game for you.  Also get the DLC. It lets ya level to 99, adds some cool extra fighters, and more masters and moves and gear.

After not playing much DBZ games since Tenkaichi 3 (and being disappointed with what I've seen/rented), this feels extremely refreshing and it's great that DBZ has finally made its way onto PC!  Pros:  -You can make your own character! -MMO-lite systems to ensure that you'll be playing for quite some time.  -Character progression feels pretty straightforward and your power rise is noticeable. -Parrallel Quests have a good amount of replayability. -You can play with friends/others and do non-story quests together or beat each other up in PvP.  -Lots of skills, costumes, z-souls, and other stuff to unlock. -Looks freaking great. Everything feels very fast-paced and flying especially feels great. -Follows the deceased Dragon Ball Online's storyline, which is great to see a recovery of. -Has so much freaking potential just waiting to get unlocked in future DLCs/patches/sequels. -Dat DBZ Abridged Nappa cameo.  Cons: -Occasional bugs. Namely getting stuck in place and being unable to move (happens to both NPCs and Players). -Clothing gives stats... kind of defeats the purpose of collecting costumes and creating a custom character if it hurts your performance to a degree. -Combat feels a bit wonky and takes time to get used to. Could be more fluid. -Story is patchy in areas due to the nature of the character roster. -Doesn't really touch on Dragon Ball at all, just Dragon Ball Z and some of the movies. -Best played with a controller, in my opinion.  Either/Or: -Customization is there, but it's a bit limited in areas where it could be better (i.e. Saiyans don't have tails, and most clothing can't be recolored to your choosing). -In general feels like they could do a lot more with the game, but at the same time there's plenty as-is. -Server stability is wonky at the moment, but that's to be expected with such a big launch. -The character roster is a bit questionable in areas (i.e. picking fodder characters Appule/Raspberry over Zarbon/Dodoria or even Cui), but covers the main stuff and a bit more. -Things like transformations and powering up are a bit wonky because they take up skill slots, hampering your ability to use all four skill slots for the numerous physical/ki/defensive abilities.  Overall this is ALMOST what I could consider as THE definitive DBZ experience. If they do a sequel that improves on existing systems and fills the character roster out, it would be an easy 10/10. For now though I'd give this a good 9/10 for DBZ fans, 8/10 for non-DBZ fans.

I debated over whether or not to give this game a thumbs up or a thumbs down. There's a lot I like about it, and a lot I dislike about it. The most compelling factor is the custom character aspect of this game, which has separate sexes and races (for most races.) The customization options are alright, though I honestly would have liked a bit more. I also owned Ultimate Tenkaichi for the Xbox 360, which dealt with the character customization too. On actually making a character, while only for that one race, UT actually felt a bit more in depth in certain ways. There were things like auras and fighting styles you could choose from, which felt nice. Also, going Super Saiyan didn't just turn your hair yellow, it changed shape and such, as it should. It's simple things, but they made your character feel all the more like your character. When it comes to the clothing, I find a problem with the fact that they give stats. Instead of just dressing how you like, you're going to want to pick certain clothing just because it's the best one stat wise for your character. Saying this, however, I do appreciate the fact that you can have different set loadouts to choose from, so it offsets the problem slightly. These are some of the minor problems, and I have other small grievances as well, such as the fact that you have to walk back to the parable quest area after each quest, but they aren't game breakingly terrible. On the large problem side, I have two. The most prevalent one, which has been mentioned before, is the servers. There's nothing quite like paying $50 for a game to have the wonderful experience of watching a circle spin on the loading screen, having your game get stuck there, or all around crashing. The problem isn't mine alone, as I have 5 other friends all going through the same thing. This is a game breaking problem, considering I can't play it when I want, and when I can, it's after getting on and off the servers over and over. They really dropped the ball on this one. The other problem is the ease of which people can cheat on this game. 3 of my aforementioned friends have done it themselves already, so I know it's relatively easy. If a player wants to cheat on their own game, I don't care very much, but other players are using it to play against each other online in competitive battles, and there are no repercussions to this. All of this combined has marred my experience with this game as a whole. On the positive, however, I do have some to say. For one, it's a Dragonball game with character customization. Sweet. The option to play with up to two players online in the missions is also a huge plus. It has a DBZ Sagas feel to it, but done better. The combat as a whole is better than UT, which was that games biggest downfall, and it flows pretty smoothly. When it comes to using moves, this game is nice in the fact that not everyone is going to use the same moves. Most moves have drawbacks of some sort to them so, unlike UT, not everyone has the need to run a whole kit of Broly's moves for the simple fact that they're the best. I currently run one of Nappa's moves, which happened to be the first thing I unlocked. I was really worried about that aspect, and I was pleasantly surprised by it. The story line was okay, though rather short. The parallel missions make up for that though, and the acquisition of items and moves is clearly the focus of the game anyway. Replay value is high in the sense of you having enough character slots to have a character of each sex/race possible, but all items and equipment is shared through each character. That is a good thing, and a bad. Once I get everything initially, I can just power level all my other characters to a high level. Regardless, I still see a lot of play time coming from the game, even if half of it is at the loading screen. Overall, I've enjoyed playing the game, when I can, and I give it a thumbs up in the hopes that they fix the server issue.

Xenoverse is a game with some problems.  The character roster is severely lacking, combat is pretty simplistic, online rarely functions properly (and when it does, you're far more likely to encounter a cheater than not), the transformations are... poorly implemented, the environments are very small, and the visuals fail to adequately capture Akira Toriyama's classic style.  But none of that matters. Why? Because it's a fun Dragonball game--something we haven't seen in years. With a robust character-creation system--something we've never seen before. And an original storyling that's actually fun--something we've never seen before.  Being able to create your own Dragonball character and go wild, levelling up, completing quests, learning new skills, etc., etc. is an absolute joy for any Dragonball fans. So while the game as a whole may still be inferior to the oft-praised Budokai Tenkaichi 3, it's a helluva lot better than any other Dragonball game since then, and is just as promising of a game as the first Tenkaichi is.  If DIMPs can keep the license, I am very excited to see this series improve. If any game could steal the crown from Tenkaichi 3, it would be a XenoVerse sequel.

It's been a long time since I had any hope for a Dragon Ball game. Xenoverse promised a lot but did it ultimately hold on to those promises? Well sort of yes. It did. This is my short and rather biased review of Xenoverse.  Dragon Ball Xenoverse is the next game in the series of Dragon Ball games released by Dimps. People who have made fairly succesfull Dragon Ball titles in the past such as the Budokai series. The game's story takes place in a time when a group of people called the Time Patrol notice there are several fractions of time being disturbed causing history to change. Since violating the timeline is a bad thing and there seems to be a lack of heroes these days the Dragon Balls are used to summon a hero strong enough to help solving this time crisis. This hero is you.  The game starts by the player creating his or her own Dragon Ball hero. There are five different races. Majin, the pink Buu looking creatures. Saiyans, everybody's favourite spiky haired monkey people. Earthlings, your plain general people on the earth (which are oddly missing all the animal variety of people you see thorough the show). Namekians, the green slug men from space. And lastly the Freeza race, everybody knows Freeza, right?  Each of the game's races and genders have different stats so race does matter. For example Namekians are tough and generate stamina quickly on their own while Freeza race is extremely fast and has a stunning Ki attack replacing the regular Ki pew pews.  You get to customize your character. This includes mainly the size and what your face looks like plus colouring the whole thing. The real customization after that comes from the game itself. There are tons of different outfits and accessories to buy using the inworld money Zeni which you earn by the truckload while playing. All in all the variety of user created characters is pretty good. It could be better for sure but it works as it is for now and you can see plenty of different people online, provided if you actually ever get online.  You're then unleashed into the game world, TokiToki city, which is where everything in the game happens. In that place you physically walk in the Dragon Ball world, talk to people, take on quests, buy things and all that stuff. It reminds me of Fable 3's horrible Sanctuary in a way, but in this case it doesn't bother me since it's only a world you move in. All the important thigns such as choosing skills, increasing your characters attributes and putting on accessory or clothes is still handled through a regular menu options.  Dragon Ball Xenoverse looks really good. The visuals are nailed very well and the game looks like the anime and manga. And they even got the lip sync done right this time. There's not much to say about the graphics. I guess the only part which I didn't like too much was some of the ground textures in TokiToki looking out of place and too realistic for a DB game but that's about it.  The game opens up with the main quest for you to follow and once you advance in that you open up more options. For example when you begin the game the stores in the city are closed, but after a while you're introduced to all of this one by one untill you everything from shops to paraller missions are accessible to you. Talking about paraller missions.  Along with the game's main story you unlock a large variety of paraller missions. These are 'What if' stories basically where you end up doing plenty of different things. Each quest has its main objective and also hidden goals which you only find out by trial and error. Knowing what happens in the manga and anime though can help you unlock some of the hidden goals. Doing these missions is your bread and butter when it comes to leveling up your character. There's also a random loot system for each of these missions and you may earn rewards from healing items to different outfits and most importantly new skills, depending on how well you beat the mission.  Leveling up grants you a level, which makes you stronger against lower level enemies and also gives you three skill points to share between six diffrerent stats: Max health, Max Ki, Max, stamina, Basic Attacks, Strike Supers and Ki Blasts. Putting a point in any of these stats increases their effectiveness and you can end up with a great variety of different stat builds which in turn lets you play your character the way you want.  Fighting in the game looks very familiar to all of those people who have played Budokai Tenkaichi or Raging Blast. Characters soar in the air and shoot beams at eachother and punch themselves through walls. The way the fighting works has a simple beat 'em up formula to it, but don't let it fool you. Mastering it takes a while and learning what move set and play style works the best for you. The game has basic melee attacks light and heavy ones. You can chain these attacks together freely to create insanely long combos if you know what you're doing. In addition you have four super attacks which can be Ki balls, beams, explosions and the like or melee strikes such as the melee combos from the show some people might be familiar with. There are also supporting skills which get you out of troubles, charge your characters Ki or just generally make a particular situation easier for your character. You can also equip two special moves which are extremely powerfull but require a lot of Ki to use, such as Reccoom's Ultra Fighting what ever Bomber? or Kid Buu's planet destroying energy ball. Combining these is fun and works very well and I was positively surprised to see how amazing the fighting system is even with all its simplicity. It's not all good though. The controls can be frustratingly clunky to a new player and even after a while once you get used to taking your character out there to fight people it still feels needlessly sticky. Also Ki attacks aren't really what you would expect or what you've been used to if you've played any of the Budokai series games for example. The attacks are done right and they look the way they should, but the 'oomph' is missing. No big explosions, no blinding flashes. Even the strongest attacks just feel dissapointingly washed out and simple. It's a bit like throwing beach balls at people. The impact is the same.  The game is cearly meant to be played with friends and online. The AI in the game is horrendously bad. Not the enemy AI, the team AI is what I'm talking about. If you have NPC's helping you or you get to choose people from the roster for the paraller quests be ready to dissapoint and rip your hair out. The friendly AI is not only dumb and useless. It tries to help you. Emphasis is on the word TRY. More often than not your AI partners just get in your way, ruin your long, game winning combos or special moves and generally act as a constant annoyance. Luckily you don't have to take those people with you for the quests if you don't want to, but there are still the mission specific AI allies who are out there, looking to get themselves killed, especially if your mission objective is to... say, have that guy survive till the end.  The online part of the game, at the time of writing, is still broken. You can't get online and it's no possible for me to interact with people who play the game online. So I have no experience of creating groups and taking on quests together. I managed to play a few one on one matches and a single paraller quest by being directly invited into a game. It provided to be good fun and I really enjoyed it the little time it lasted.  As my final words I would suggest getting this game. It's hands down the best Dragon Ball game to come out in a long time and if you're a fan of the games, shows or the manga you most likely wont be dissapointed. The game has plenty of content to keep you busy for a while and once the online part of the game gets fixed to a playable state it can only get better.

So with me just having beaten the main story, here is a run down;  The good +Solid fighting mechanics  +Great fun with friends  +Custom character creation is solid  +Wide variety of moves to choose from  +Like Smash Bros it is easy to pull moves off, the hard part is using them at the right time. AKA Easy to pick up, harder to  master.  +Decent story (Though it is basically fanfiction of a self-insersion Deviantart OC, ha)  +Seems to be a decent amount of post story content to do, namely PvE content in both solo and co-op.  The bad  -Silly hub world that could just as easily have been a menu, very slow to walk through and key NPCs I want to speak to spawn at random, often not appearing at all, only shuffle about when I do a mission and get back.  -RNG drop rates of certain skills, equipment and z-souls is total bullcrap. A mentor asks me to get a specific soul from a mission I could do as early as lv10, I've now beaten the main story hours later and despite over 20 attempts I have yet to get the z-soul I want.   To summarise; in each mission you have X drop, to get X drop Y event must occur, Y event has Z requirement during the mission. Such as beating all enemies in under 5 minutes which spawns an additional enemy that MIGHT drop the item you want. But here's the kicker; that event only has a CHANCE of occuring in itself when the requirements are met. This does not belong in a fighting game.  -Servers are crapping themselves right now, BanCo is aware of it however so this may be fixed eventually.  -Sadly, the game has NO anti-cheating measure. There are already trainers and ini tweaks around which are easily used and make your character absurdly powerful, beyond what is actually possible. This also works in PvP.  -Speaking of PvP; like all DBZ games, if someone picks an extremely powerful character from the show, you may as well give up on the spot. SSJ4 Vegeta for example, who was a pre-order bonus only of all things, is frequently picked because he simply has an absurd amount of health, damage and so on compared to about 90% of the roster. If you're expecting balanced PvP, look elsewhere, unless you're okay with choosing powerful characters all the time.  -PC specific bugs, Examples; -Teleporting doesn't work properly, instead of moving you behind the target you just 'blink' on the spot. This works fine on the console versions. -If you use an ulti ability, pause, alt-tab, tab back in and unpause, your character will perform the ultimate move AGAIN without costing ki or stamina. This does not work in multiplay as it requires a pause but it makes a lot of PvE very easy if abused. -Some people are reporting the ki blast effects are not displaying correctly  -AI cheats a bit, having infinite ki and stamina (Not visible to the player, but when an AI spams ulti's something is up).  -Some PvE fights are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ without absurd amounts of healing items, many of these can only be done solo, no friendly AI or co-op.   So, would I recommend it? Yes. If you are a fan of DBZ, this is a very good release. Non-DBZ fans however may find little to like as the whole thing is basically just fabservice. If you're on the fence, wait and see if some of these issues are cleaned up in the coming weeks or months. The combat isn't as finely tuned as Tenkaichi nor is the roster as big but it's perfectly good as is.

Unfortunately, Dragon Ball Xenoverse is a very unpolished and frustrating game.  Spelling mistakes (such as misspelling Beerus' name) plague this game, which is a big, red flag for a game priced at 50 euro. Apart from that, Xenoverse is simply put, a very poor Dragon Ball game. Excluding certain story characters such as Zarbon; Dodoria; Android 16; Dr. Gero; Imperfect and Semi-Perfect Cell or Majin Vegeta, it also skips a huge chunk of the Sagas presented in Dragon Ball Z.  Due to not including the necessary characters. The Namek Saga starts off with the Ginyu Force because Cui, Dodoria and Zarbon aren't present. The Cell Saga begins with Perfect Cell because Imperfect and Semi-Perfect Cell aren't present. The Android Saga doesn't include Androids 16, 19 or Dr. Gero. The Majin Buu Saga skips everything related to Gohan and Videl, Majin Vegeta and the Supreme Kai. It just feels lazy.   The game is riddled with artificial difficulty and grinding, too. You will have to fight multiple opponents that can very easily stunlock you by spamming super or ultimate attacks. Very often, opponents will have Super Armour (or was it called Hyper Armour?) too, meaning you can't even stun them by attacking.  It's no surprise so many players are resorting to spamming ultimate attacks while transformed as Super Saiyan.  The game prides itself on the ability to create your own character too, but this doesn't stand out much either. You get a few races to pick from (Freeza's, Namekian, Majin, Earthling or Saiyan), where Earthlings and Saiyans have the exact same options for customization. As Majin, you get the choice between Fat Buu or female Kid Buu(-ish); no Super Buu at all. You can't even change your Ki colour or your fighting style (your regular punches and kicks). Why can't we opt to take the same fighting style as Vegeta, Piccolo or Freeza? You can train under all of them, but they only give you a few super and ultimate attacks instead.  The last point is grinding. Yes, this game includes the ability to trade items, but only the very low levelled ones. For the rest, you'll have to resort to grinding. If you aren't lucky, you might have to spend hours upon hours redoing the same mission for that one attack, or that one piece of clothing you want.

After playing my fair share of Single- and Mutliplayer in  Dragon Ball Xenoverse , I unfortunatly can't really recommend it. It's not extremly terrible of course, but the negative points are pretty overwhelming, once they start to actually occure. But here is a typical pros and cons list.   Pros:  - The fighting system is pretty intuitive and easy to learn, yet hard to master. Zooming around in huge 3D areas and pounding enemies into the ground or mountains is super fun. - All animations and sounds are as close to the anime as it can get. You get a little reaction shot for super moves, your character shouts it's name, etc. - There is a universe of possibilities for character customisation. Most likely every costume, attack and super move that ever occured in the manga or anime, and probably more, are in this game. You can unlock those via the story missions or parallel quests. - Hence, you can level up your character and invest points in stats to form him/her like you wish. You can be a melee powerhouse or a ki-blasting ranged fighter.  - You replay every important fight in the story mode with your custom character, from Raditz to Beerus, the whole Saga is there. - You can gather the seven Dragon Balls to get Shenron to grant you a wish! Pretty cool! - The voice acting is just like in the anime!   Cons:  - The voice acting is just like in the anime! - The music is repetative and more or less not even existent. - NPCs never shut up in fights. They repeat the same lines over and over, its extremly annoying. You can mute the voices in the options, sure, but that also mutes fighting grunts which I would like to have. - The story is nothing super exciting or original. Bad guys try to alter the time lines and destroy the universe or whatever, you're a time cop and have to stop them. - The hub world was a terrible idea. It's slow and just annoying to get around in. - Loading times are pretty long, worst is the simple connecting to the server. - When you fail a story mission, you have to skip through all the cutscences again, instead of just starting over the fight. - While the fighting is pretty fun, the experience gets pretty much drowned by some super annoying things:   Sometimes the camera lock doesn't work properly and you shoot your super into nothingness. When someone hits the ground, even NPC enemies, they gain invicibilty frames, which cancels the damage for most epic combos. Pound your enemy to the ground and blast them with a charged Kamehameha? Won't do any damage. You can switch targets with the right stick, but the portals with which you change areas can be targeted aswell, even when enemies are around. When you lock on on a distant enemy, another just can zoom in front of you and start attacking you, without you even noticing. Friendly NPCs who have to survive sometimes, don't know how to dodge enemy super attacks and die quickly. The AI in general is pretty bad. The list go's on...  - There are no ingame stats for items or skills what so ever. Wanna know how much damage this skill does in comparision to your other? Have to try it out first. - The game is entirely based on RNG. You need a certain item or skill from a certain parallel quest? Well, good luck, for it is luck and luck alone that even the requirements are met for the item to drop. - Most parallel quests are just recycled, you fight the same round up over and over again. Super boring. - And probably the worst about the whole game:  Because of the RNG and increasing difficulty in the story mode, it is a gigantic grind fest.   Until I hit the point in the story mode in which I had to fight the two androids, it was pretty fine. Cell was ok to fight, but 17 and 18 pretty much insta killed me without any chance to react. Fine, I thought, doing more parallel quests, unlocking more stuff and so on, it's fun. But holy cow, the parallel quests get longer and longer, and you have to do like 3-4 of them get a level up and 3 points to increase your stats. (Wow) And it's aaaaalways the same!  This is the kind of game which lures you in with exciting gameplay and hooks you with unlocks and motivation, but the longer you play it, the more you realise it's unfortunatly riddled with flaws and bad design choices which makes the experience annoying and not fun anymore.  Edit: After I managed to unlock the Super Saiyan ability for my female Saiyan, I beat the whole story mode in one sitting around lvl 35. How? Because you can exploit the NPC's easily with an ability called 'Vacation Delete.' Super Saiyan let's you spam ki-skills with no limit, just draining the bars slowly. This ultimate attack has a big hitbox, does moderate to high damage and stuns the enemy for like 5 seconds. You do it over and over and over, and the enemy has no way to get away until they're knocked down. How did they not change this? I cant believe it's intentional. Completly broken.  Also to mention, if you're a die hard fan of the franchise you will get enjoyment out of this game, for a while at least. It's the holy grail of Dragon Ball fanservice, if you will. And if you like this kind of grind go for it, I guess, but not for the full price, game wise it's definitly not worth that amount.

In short: I do recommend this game, but only to hardcore dbz-fans who do not mind grinding for equipment. If you're one of those people, rest assured, you'll get your moneys worth out of this game. If you're not, you better stay away from this one. Save your money for a sequel.  Extended info: Despite this game having great customization which you can find in both equipment and the way your character gains strength as you level up. (You gain status points which you can use to increase their offensive or defensive capabilities like you see in many rpgs.) It fails on a few key elements.  First and foremost, there is the AI in dragonball xenoverse. You'll often hear people complaining about the difficulty of xenoverse, and where in some games this comes from a dangerous but fair AI (-read 'Dark Souls'-) in xenoverse the difficulty comes from the unbalanced power of the AI opponents.   All fighters in xenoverse have a stamina bar, and if you want to use evasive moves, or block incoming attacks, your stamina will drop. The problem is that many of these evasive moves also inflict damage on the attacking enemy. In a player versus player match this would not pose a threat but the AI seems to have a different stamina bar that regenerates ridiculously fast in comparison to that of a player. This means that the AI is going to spam these evasive moves to get out of a players combo. When sooner or later you yourself run out of stamina and your opponent doesn't, be prepared to take in damage despite having the upperhand. This damage will be magnified if there is a level difference between you and your opponent. Did I mention many strong opponents can't even begin to be combo'd unless they lose stamina first?  Another issue is the hub world. I understand what the developers wanted to create, but they made some mistakes here. For one the world is far too big for what is actually in it. The running around is boring and annoying in an otherwise fast paced game. This is made worse by the fact that after each mission you'll be dropped at a difference place than where you accept missions. This should be easily fixable by adjusting 3 lines of code however.  Another thing I should mention is that there is a transformation that is only available to the saiyan race. This transformation called super saiyan, unlike its effect in the dbz universe, presents the player with a 'limited' time of being able to spam ultimate and super attacks. While this will not pose a problem in pvp to experienced players who can dodge these attacks, it does seem to be the best way to counter the unbalanced AI. This ends up demoting the at first difficult AI to nothing more than silly target practice.   Despite all of this, you can have a lot of fun teaming up with up to two friends simultaneously to tackle missions and grind for equipment. Which brings me to the last problem of this game. Many rpg games, including this one will give you slightly random rewards. This is a great way to add replayability and fun, trying to get that one special item. The problem here however is how xenoverse handles this. Instead of only rewards being random, some events that give you these chances to obtain rewards are also random. Quite a mouthful, right? Let's rephrase that, you'll have a random chance, to obtain a random chance, to obtain your item. This is simply bad design that leads to frustration. Especially considering some of these random events, aren't random, but need to be triggered by certain hidden objectives that are nowhere mentioned in the game. This way you never know if that event that might give you your desired item happened by chance, or by some random teammate's health being below a certain point when you finish the mission. A perfect example of bad design.   So, yes, this game has flaws. A lot of flaws. But there is a silver lining to it all, if you are true dragonball fan and you like games where you have to do repeated tasks to get your favorite items or level up, you'll like this game. You'll probably end up getting mad once or twice, but I can assure you it's worth a buy. If however either one of those two conditions are false. Avoid this game at all cost.

This game had potential, and while I'm writing this late, it is a re-review, as my old one simply didn't show this game for what it was.   The game is fun, but has many things that seemed lazily slapped together, such as the animations. It is also mentionable that many things don't seem thought out. The DLC was good for the first two packs, and the third was alright, but didn't even contain campaign. Pros: + Character customisation is intricate. + The controls are easier to grasp than other 3D DBZ fighters. + Finally a new story! Kind of! + Beating up enemies with other players feels great. + Collecting new items and skills can be addicting. + Large roster of fighters. Includes variations of their timeline. (e.g. Vegeta during Saiyan saga to Buu saga) + Ressurection 'F' DLC content, including Golden Freiza.  Cons: - Online matchmaking is close to dead at this stage. (By the time of this review) - PVP is unsurprisingly broken and crap. - Special/Ultimate Attacks are the only defining factor for characters. - Combat could be seen as shallow as a result. - Prepare to hear players spam their attacks continously, and give you little opportunity to contribute in a quest. - Your character only goes up to Super Saiyan 1 in appearance. - Loot awards are mostly random - Special quest conditions are only activated randomly even if you fulfill them. (e.g. Fighting Super Saiyan 2 Gohan requires beating everyone else first before Gohan. Strangely, the game will only acknowledge that you did this 25% of the time)   Conclusion: If you held off on Xenoverse, it may have been for a good reason. Still, customising and developing your own hero/heroine may grow on you. In the UK at least, finding viable matches for quests and PVP is quickly becoming hard as a lot of players have already have moved on from the game.  If a Xenoverse 2 has (ever) been announced by the time you read this review, you may be better off waiting for that.
