Warning: This review may be slightly influenced by my love for DBZ, so be advised. Now I've played through this game three times, each time just as enjoyable as the one before. I highly recommend this game, but theres some things I should mention.  Pros! This game is a great fighting game, and as with most fighting games this one is best with a controller rather than mouse and keyboard. Why I suggest using a wired controller for this is because of the way this game works, most of the time you'll be in the air fighting rather than on the ground. Without a controller it takes a bit of getting used to manuvering while flying, like rising and lowering your altitude to get closer (or further away) to your target. This leads me to another reason why using a controller is supreme. Ultimate and Super Attacks. I have to say this was probably the most fun to experiment with when your playing XENOVERSE, as your ultimates and supers can pretty much make or break your character depending on the way you go with character customization (I.E: using a ton of melee based supers when doing a Ki based character) I suggest you mess around and have fun getting your ultimates the way you like it. Now I can go on for a while about the great things in this game, like character customization. But theres somethings you should know if you plan on playing Xenoverse.  Cons: *Sigh* This game is really awesome, but some of the features can ruin your fun. Lets start with least favourite feature of this game... Random Number Generator... Oh where do I begin with this pile of crap. RNG is used for the drops in this game, which can lead to hours or days farming for a super, ultimate, item, or a piece of armor. This is probably what ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off the most in this. I spent hours farming for Super Vegeta 2 (one of the transformations) and still haven't gotten it. Even though I've gotten Z-ranks almost every time I did the mission it was on. So I spent upwards of eight or nine hours farming for it, and at some point gave up on farming for it. So if your playing through this and hoping for a certain item be prepared for either really short or a really long farming state.   Partner AI is another bad part about this game, sometimes they'll just be useless and at other times they'll be helpful. I honestly couldn't figure out how their AI works, but be prepared to revive them a few times. This brings me to my next subject.  Some story missions in this are annoying as heck at times. I'll give an example, theres a part in this game where your character has to defeat 20 enemies. Sounds simple, right? Wrong. You have to constantly protect Gohan and Krillin from getting killed, 'cause if they're killed its an instant failure. Oh and the missions don't have checkpoints, which makes this tedious along with their horrible A.I.  Okay I can go on for a couple more paragraphs on the good things and bad things about this game. But overall, the good outweighs the bad. So what rating would I give this game? I honestly would give this game a 8/10. I went into this game wanting it to be my GOTY for 2015, but I found it in my top 10 of the year. This game would be a 9/10 if it wasn't for some of the annoyances with the Parallel quests (Due to their occasional repeating of objectives), RNG, and partner A.I. If you're going to get this game I'd suggest getting it with a friend because its much better with friends, I also suggest waiting for a sale and getting the Resurrection F DLC along with it. Now go, have fun with this game. I know I did. :D

In offline play melee oriented playstyles are incredibly gimped and simply spamming beams whilst transformed is the best way to progress the story. This is a game that parades itself as a fighting game while being one of the most disturbingly unbalanced garbage piles I've ever played and I had a phase in my life where I actively seeked out bootlegs of fighting games for giggles. From giving NPCs infinite transformations, transformations which give them infinite power to spam Ultimate Attacks at will in turn, to having you fight 5-6 different enemies at once, enemies which can stunlock you forever if they so wish using those Ultimate Attacks or in other ways I may describe later.  This is a game that has possibly the worst AI ever invisoned in video games. They'll switch targets constantly and erratically, they'll spam attacks and keep you stunlocked and if I didn't know better I'd say it was ingenius and strategic but no, it's just them flopping about. It's actually kind of funny because in one instance, this I took a screenshot of actually, the AI was flying into a wall for two minutes. Two whole minutes trying to get at each other. It was nothing short of astounding and quite honestly I felt embarassed for Bamco.  This is a game that is full of bizarre bugs, horrible online play with ridiculous amunts of lag with two people, let alone 3 in co-op and boy does it go nuts if there's a 6-man match. Not only that but let's say you win a quest, you beat it... sometimes, very often, the game will decide you're not worthy and softlock. That's right, you or your friends will get stuck and the only way out is to ALT+F4 which, by the way, will incurr some penalties like getting your name turned red in the multi lobby. As an extra point sometimes it won't recognise that your friends have the DLC. If you're in a team and you try to host a DLC quest sometimes it'll just say your friends don't have it and you can't play it despite the fact that if you simply host the quest on your own anyone can join freely. I could go on about every bug I've encountered since I started playing but then I'd take weeks and that's more work than this game deserves, and likely more work than was put into developing it.  This is a game that is lazily made in overall. It has the strong taste of half-baked ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ry I've come to expect from Bamco. In this game there's 4 separate Gokus and several slots in the base one. None of these is a costume change to keep him Super Saiyan, even just as a graphical change. They all fight exactly the same with the less-than-notable differences of having alternative Super/Ultimate attacks, yes even the SSGSS Goku and SSG Goku. It should be noted, however, that he and every other character who can transform[there's not many by the way] can remain that way forever if he's fighting you, with really annoying super armour and infinite Ki to boot, which leads to infinite Kamehameha spam. It should also be noted that mods can easily mend this issue, an issue that should not be an issue at all honestly, condensing every Goku into one? Done. With extra little costume details? Sure! Transformations are also boring and lacklustre with the player character's hair not even changing if you go Super Saiyan and Super Saiyan being the only unique transformation, the other races just get left behind entirely despite being more interesting and unique to play as but that's enough nitpicking there.  Little note to leave here before I give my finishing thoughts; Customisation? Awful, lazy, horrible. That describes it. You have more options in customisation playing a Newgrounds Dress-Up game and would probably have more fun doing that. I might go do that after I finish writing this.  In summation this game is awful, it is a horrible, lazy waste of up to $70 dollars and it is a shame that something hyped up so badly ended up being such garbage. BT3, it is not. It is not even the Raging Blast games which were arguably the worst of the 3D open-world fighters in the DBZ series. Simply put, don't get this unless you're a hardcore fan of the series, even then, consider how much value you want out of those $70. Final score; Disappointment and Frustration/10. I beat this game after about 37 hours and I gotta say, it kicked ♥♥♥. There were times when I felt like Vegeta, blinded by rage, and other times when I felt like Goku, just having fun in a tough fight. I think it's an awesome game and I feel like compared to other Dragon Ball games, it really captured what it's like to fight in their universe. It's not a side scrolling beat-em-up or a 2.5D figher, it's a fighter that exists on a full landscape in which you could possibly be figthting 5 enemies at once (an actual fight).  I know some people didn't like it, but I thought the addition of custom characters really made this game. Personally speaking, when I play a game, I like to feel like I AM the character, I don't like feeling like I'm controlling a character. That's why I love games like Skyrim so much while disliking pretty much any MOBA ever made. I didn't feel like I was a coach watching Goku save the world while telling him how to do it. I felt like I was helping him in a fight he'd otherwise lose.  Something else I thoroughly enjoyed was the Master system. The Master system basically let's you train under one of Dragon Ball's many character in exchange for their occasional assistance and skills. I trained under Vegeta and learned many of his signature moves that helped me a ton along the way. You can train under all of them over time which let's you rack up an awesome roster of cool skills. I enjoyed that a lot I thought it was an awesome addition.  Now that's not to say this game was perfect either. As I said, this game took me about 37 hours to beat. However if I were to go back and start over from the beginning with my current stats and abilities, the game would probably take 3-4 hours to beat. This game suffers from what I think many many games suffer from. Using difficulty to increase the length of an otherwise contentless game. I know people have pretty much accepted that grinding is something you have to do in most modern RPGs, but I personally never fell for that. You wanna know why Skyrim is such a well-loved game? Because you can get 100+ hours out of it without having to do a lick of grinding because there's so much content. Dragon Ball doesn't have that. I spent most of the game grinding because between every chapter of the game there's a huge difficulty spike. That's not to say it's a bad game, but I would have much rather seen new story arcs or more parts to each chapter.  Another issue I had was parallel quests. Parallel Quests are basically different variations of the actual storyline that you get to play for fun and rewards. But for me their main use was for grinding on something besides the plot. See when I was first learning about Parallel Quests I thought it was gonna be like the Dream Log from One Piece: Pirate Warriors 3. See in the Dream Log, you get to experience missions that would never happen in the actual storyline. Luffy and Doflamingo could be fighting to stop Ace and Nami from escaping Impel Down. Bat ♥♥♥♥ crazy stuff that is insanely fun. Instead I found that Parallel Quests were basically alternate timelines of the original Dragon Ball story. There are a few that are pretty crazy, like fighting off a bunch of Cell Juniors while searching for the dragonballs. And others like where I literally just did the final battle with Frieza but instead of Goku, it was me. Both games were made by Bandai Namco so I feel like they really missed an opportunity to do something similar to the Dream Log but instead I got Parallel Quests which are only fun the first few times, after that they're just grinding material.   Overall, I think this game deserves a 7/10. Awesome fighting, Customizeable character. Too much grinding, not enough real content

[TL;DR]  The game is by far very fun and you will be playing a part in all the epic moments in the Dragon Ball series. However, server is extremely unstable for the moment and there are a good number of game-breaking bugs. Those are killing the game right now. Keep an eye on the forums and patch notes to decide before you get the game. [TL;DR]   I will start by stating that I am glad to see a Dragon Ball game on Steam! If you are a fan of the Dragon Ball series, you don't want to miss this.  Pros:    The game is smooth when it works, you will be using all those supers and ultimates in the series.     Co-op is fun with a friend and enjoy the epic moments in Dragon Ball like you actually play a part.     Content for the price is fair in my opinion. You get quite a bit to work with, I love both the story and the parallel quests.     Online battles and ranking. PVP always plays a good factor.   Cons:    [Major] For some reason, some of the game mechanics are tied to FPS and there are some gamebreaking bugs. Most of the in-game items or functions are working only at 30FPS. They fixed 1 and many other appears. For example, power capsule not giving you the correct amount of energy. All the effects will be lost when you have VSYNC on. Recover all your health with a simple punch when its only suppose to give you a little amount of health.     [Major] Server is extremely unstable for the moment. They have released a patch but it didn't seem to resolve the issue. They are still actively working on it. Problem with the server not only affect online plays, but also offline plays. The game decided to have you connect to the server before entering the single lobby, which is a bad idea. Yes, you can disconnect and goes back to the title screen during offline play.     Drop rate was too high. They fixed it by lower it down but now its way too low. I reckon they could implement a better drop system. So yes, you need to farm hard ♥♥♥ to get something you want.     Rating is also strange sometimes. You fulfill the hidden conditions of the quest but there is a good chance that nothing will show up. Again, you may need to farm the same mission again and again just to get the rank.     Adding friend is annoying because there is a high chance that you could not find your friend in the player list. During group play, instead of creating a room and choose quests to proceed, you have to host a quest and invite every time.      PVP winning condition has its flaws. Some player could just hit and run and wait until the timer is done and wins. Ultimate spam could also be fixed by putting a cast time interval between.    I like the game but I am not going to recommend it to anyone until they fix the major issues. Bad server always kills a game.

Having played most, if not all of the PS2-era DBZ games and Sparkling, I must say I'm very disappointed with this one. It lacks all the energy and speed that the earlier Budokai games had, with you mashing out the same basic combos over and over, leaving you to punch, knock away, follow, and repeat over and over. You can get strung into a unblockable (once one hits) flurry of staggering ki attacks, and if you're versus more than one person at a time, you might as well turn the game off. The locking-on is abysmal, and I've lost matches purely because I wasn't able to target the person I needed to. And let's not forget that when you teleport behind an enemy doing an energy attack to avoid it--assuming your block/teleport button works, which it doesn't always-- you will still be hit for full damage by a forward-firing beam despite being 180 degrees behind them.  The game's tutorial--given to you after no less than three full fights, which feel awful because you don't know what you're doing--is so bare-bones that it doesn't even explain basic mechanics like deflecting ki, requiring almost immediate reference to player-written guides, which is proof of incredibly bad design.  Running around the hub-world is boring, the Parellel Quests are already getting repetitive after 6 or so, the graphics have that ugly GT gloss that the series now always seems to have, and while I chose not to buy it myself--the DLC is a disappointing rip-off. More time seems to have been put into the customisation than the fighting mechanics, which I could understand if this were some lavish MMO, but this is a game I will be playing solo, and for 'that' it feels hollow. Speaking of MMO design, all items rely on RNG drops and grinding the same levels over and over again, and progression in the main story REQUIRES grinding for XP in patrol missions, which is the definition of lazy pacing and length-padding.  This is a game with a good concept and bad execution. Most of the new voice actors are fine, but so far Trunks, Frieza and Cell all stand out as being completely terrible.  EDIT: This game has unskippable cut-scene, such as entries or revivals, which halt gameplay - but not pause it. If you were in the middle of something, it will be as if you just stopped playing, and any special attacks will be cancelled. Get into a fight where lots of people come in? (like the final Captain Ginyu training mission) You won't get a single special attack out, and you'll waste all your ki because of these cutscenes. I lost two ultimates in a row because someone entered after I started it. Absolute garbage. This game needs to stop pretending like it's a real fighting game but giving ever item stats too - I want to customise my character, but I'm locked into a certain set of clothes because of my build. Same thing for alternate costumes on main characters.  There is also no option to retry a mission if you fail. You must endure the failure, listen to a character tell you you're ♥♥♥♥, go back to the hub world and manually start the mission all over again. ALSO, all dialogue refers to you as a male, regardless of the gender of your character, and the single-player missions always refer to you as if you were part of a group, though you cannot co-op for the main story, as far as I know. There are also really botched translations in parts, and bizzare moments when your custom character speaks to others but makes no sound - which you might consider standard, but your selected voice speaks attack names, so why not the odd scentence too? It makes the whole thing feel very fake and transparent.

The gameplay itself is pretty fun - when you get to play it. The combat feels a bit like Budokai, but I definitely preferred Budokai 2. But it is still fun and worth playing if you're a fan of DBZ titles.  While the game does incorporate a lot of new elements, none of them feel fully flushed out. The Toki Toki hub world is just a huge pain to navigate, and why did they even give a jump button to you in that area? I like the student system, where you can learn skills from a chosen master, and gain items pertinent to that character.   The story is passable, and the voice acting is pretty much what you'd expect from a DBZ title, but the major disappointment is the Parallel Quest system. I think this could have been a great way to introduce battle scenarios, but it just feels like more of the same of the main questline. Yes, there are items you can go around and hunt, but it wouldn't feel like nearly as much of a chore if after every parallel quest it didn't start you back at the Toki Toki world entrance. That just makes me not want to do PQs.  But then comes the games absolute biggest flaw, and something that I feel is worthy of a refund: The constant disconnects from the game server. I understand that I can play single player without interruption by restarting Steam in Offline mode, but that is a major inconvenience when I can just choose any other title from my catalogue and play that instead. But what if I want to play with friends? Well, you just have to put up with being disconnected after just about every other quest. It is horrendously implemented, moreso than any other only mediocre-implementation of features.  All in all I would not recommend this game and I am quite disappointed in it for a variety of reasons.

So I dont typically like many fighting games, and while I do like the anime Im not really a fan boy. If I 'were' though Id tell you how excited I am for the new Frieza movie coming out in japan sometime this April ;) Since the servers seem to be functioning now Im editing my review, but honestly I still cant give game companies a free pass when they release games in such a broken state. Plus there are STILL issues with playing online, such as the broken 'idle checker' that will boot you even when you've just come out of a game.  'Would it really have been so hard to just...?' In depth review is as follows - you were warned.    1= Now I don't mind RNG in games, but Xenoverse relies on it to a rediculous extent. Not only is the loot not explained but it has only a chance to drop if you meet the hidden criteria for it to drop. What makes it worse is many PQ missions play out similarly. For instance many events require something to happen, say killing a specific character last. And even if you fulfill these special requirements the event that is supposed to happen might not even occur due to no fault of your own, simply RNG. It makes the whole experience largely a guessing game of what you have to do to make something happen to fight someone to maybe get a drop from them at those times. For example when farming Brollys clothes, you have to sit back doing nothing and wait for the terrible AI to decide when it will fight and kill Videl, then hope Brolly kills Goten and Trunks so Gohan appears. This gives the best CHANCE of Brolly deciding to revive. Then after you kill him the second time [if he revives] you still only have a small chance to get an item. Much of the game works like this, its lame.  2= Now a very close second, the lack of any actual chat in game. I mean for crying out loud... this is obviously a straight up console port with no love for PC enthusiasts. You're limited in game by already scripted comments like 'Hello' and 'yes' and 'no'. What is wrong with just a chat lobby for people? Maybe the ability to private message someone or send someone little messages through steam at the very least? It really makes me wish steams default ways of doing things didnt prevent you from simply messaging people who you just met and havent added to your friends list. Anyway, one particularly annoying situation is I'll be in the game trying to offer some help to anyone who wants it and Im limited to 'Seeking Friends' 'I'll help!' and so on, and then when we set up a team we STILL lack in game voice options until we actually make a room and pick a level. So theres litterally no way I can ask someone which specific mission theyd like help with until we're already in a random mission. *shakes head* Communication is important, and the ball gets dropped hard here. This is on PC, I have a keyboard, LET ME USE IT! *shakes game*  3= No online story mode, wouldn't have been hard *sigh*. Now I understand that its perhaps for a more immersive single player experience but I would have liked the ability to at least make a new character and do a co op campaign with friends or something. Perhaps be able to go back to already beaten missions and play them again with friends to get a better rank... something at least? But especially for a game that requires you to be connected to online servers at all times [unless you set steam to offline mode] why isnt there more content to do online with people?Theres a lot of possible content here that would be fun to play, yet we are limited to side quests and versus mode only. I really wish there was more co op content in the game other than side quests. As it is, other than pvp theres not a lot replayability here yet.  4= The online play has problems too. Now I wont get too much into bugs, or balancing issues. I wont get into lame combat mechanics like ult spamming and such either. I mean the actual game play... for one the Host has a very large advantage since the game lags and desyncs a lot, which strikes me as odd if we're supposed to be connecting to some official game server right? Im not sure what the purpose of these servers are if people are hosting their own games honestly. Lots of times attacks that should hit miss, and in a fighting game that relies a lot on well timed blocks and split second timing of attacks to get a hit in this can easily be a game changer, or, a game ruiner. And like I said earlier, most of the game seems centered on pvp fighting, it really wouldnt be as big an issue if the single player or co op parts had more replayability.  5= Lack of customization, sorta. This will be my longest and most in depth critique, and I admit its mostly opinion. Dont get me wrong theres lots of options and outfits, and even the ones with the most stats barely affect anything so its pretty close to being entirely cosmetic other than for hard core minmaxers. My problem stems from more deep seeded issues. For instance most of the outfits aren't tintable/recolorable, which would have been pretty easy. Theres also no way to take a favorite outfit of yours and make your own version of it, say with your own preference of stats or styles, so if you wanted your character to have goku's torn up gi and be bare chested then your SOL. Theres other problems too, if you dont want to be a fat buu you have to make a female buu. And while I understand that namekians are genderless why couldnt we have female frieza's? Speaking of, different genders have different stats, as well as your size and such. Its strange that your appearance wouldnt be completely cosmetic considering almost everything else is, but my suggestion is if your wanting a female character make her as large as possible since they're super tiny. My first Saiyan couldnt even see over the counter at the default height, and even at max height possible she's right in between Gohans and Videl's height, for reference.  Otherwise, Buu's and Frieza's have no different forms. And super saiyans, well where do I begin?Theres only SS1 and 2, theres a super vegeta form but its the same... its supposed to increase your ki blasts a little more than super saiyan instead of melee but Im not seeing it so if the difference there they probably ♥♥♥♥ed up and put the decimal in the wrong place so its probably like 1% and 3% difference instead of 10 and 30 or whatever. I'll go super saiyan when a friend is looking at me on their scouter to see my power levels and it doesnt change at all. It would have also been nice if our hair changed AT ALL when we went super saiyan. While it DOES turn colors, the style is completely static. I was really hoping that my hair would spike up and nope, the model didnt change what-so-ever. Would it have really been that hard to include a normal and super saiyan hair style versions?  Lastly for complaints about customization, it seems the same voices are used for all races. I was expecting different races to sound different but humans sound the same as every other race... which is a let down. Would it really have been that hard to get a few more voice actors for a major title game? Your character is stoically silent in the story mode anyway so all your character says is names of attacks while battling... like SPECIAL BEAM CANNON! and 'Hi' or 'whatsup?'    Otherwise, all that aside [and it is a lot] the gameplay is amazing. Its primarily an online fighting game so I think thats where the majority of people are going to be concerned with. Balance, bugs, latency, etc are all issues but Ive ran out of room in my review, sorry.

I had waited for this game for quite a long time and had great expectation regarding it. Unfortunatly, I must admit that this game is quite a bit of disapointment for me...   Positive:  - The main good point in favor of this game is the game, which is the core element in game development.   This game is build on a somewhat MMORPG feeling with the whole quest, duel and arena system.  You are not playing one of the main serie character, but rather your very own custom character (either human, sayien, namek, boo or freeza race). Lot's of customization is possible.  You can upgrade the stats of your avatar and the gear (even tough you can't change the color, what a shame) just like any RPG.  Yet, the gameplay is the one of a fighting game, let's say fighting/RPG (since you can use item during fight).  - As an inveterate fan of Dragon ball, I can't help but to like this new way of presenting the story of this classic Shonen.  Yet, the game in itself is now half as story immesing as Naruto shippuden : ultimate ninga storm 3 is...   Negative :  - The soundtrack is sincerly annoying and I'm not even talking about the poor english dubbling.  OK, purists will tell me to play in the original version with subtitle, but hey! There are some people too lazy to read when they are playing...  In any cases, the soundtrack annoy me so bad that I'm turning the sound off when not playing the main campain.  - The cell shading is not bad, yet it is not extra-ordinary at all. The colors and the lights are rendered somehow a little bit weird...  Globally, the graphics is far below games like Naruto shippuden : ultimate ninga storm 3 for cell shading or final fantasy 13 for regular japanese graphics.  It's a shame when a brand new game can't compete with way older games...  - No matter at which time I play, it is always a challenge to connect to the server. If I ever manage to log in, I can't even play more than a single quest without being disconnected...  Why the h*** can't we play offline?   Conclusion :  This game what most definitly build on good intention. Yet, no matter how good or bad a game is, it cannot be anything but a bad game if you can't manage to play it.  I mean, with the season pass DLC, this game cost something like 83 canadian dollars. That's quite a lot of money!  I hate those new generation game that you absolutly new to connect on game server to play. That mean that you can't play them when there are under server maintenance, when your internet is down or, like in this case, the server is most obviously not designed to support so much players.  Anyone would agree that never being able to play a game you paid good money for is unnacceptable. This is not a 5 dollars indy game, this is supposed to be a AAA game...   I would recommend to wait for them to fix all the server bug before ever considering buying this game.   In the meaning time, you should consider, if you don't already own it, Naruto shippuden : ultimate ninga storm 3 for a way better fighting shonen based game.

Flawed perfection.  That oxymoron is what I use to describe this game. In that regard, I will talk about everything that's wrong with it before I praise it.  Dragonball Xenoverse has some of the most idiotic A.I. I've seen in a game in recent years (Although the worst goes to that one Aliens game, I'd say. You know the one.). In a PQ, you can choose two of any of the characters you've unlocked to assist you, which is good, because some of the quests are tough, even at the beginning. The problem arises in that they are basically just meat shields to take hits for you and deal some light damage. They rarely use their super moves, and they never, ever use their ultimates or transformations (where applicable... or not applicable, as the case may be.)  In addition, the enemy characters may just float harmlessly in front of you, begging to be hit. On the flipside of that coin, some of them will be absolutely ruthless. They will spam their super and ultimate moves, and chase you down afterward to kick the living ♥♥♥♥ out of you. Granted, most of that happens in later difficulties, but more than you'd expect. In one of the later quests, where you have to fight every single Z-Fighter (From Yamcha to SS3 Goku, in several different areas, each with their own team of enemies), going throught the portal into th final zone greets you with Super Saiyan Goku, Gohan, and Goten. More often then not, both Goku and Gohan will fire Kamehamehas at you the second they see you, while little Goten hits you with a barrage of blasts that, while inaccurate, can lock you in place fairly well... right before the Kamehamehas hit. You'll likely die immediately, because of course.  There are a few glitches, too. The most notable ones seem to be in two PQs that have you collecting Dragonballs. Both have the same problem, which is that one of said balls spawn, without fail, outside the area you're aloud to traverse. And that blue, circuit-like barrier that holds you back will mock you silently.  Also, there are spelling and grammatical errors absolutely, and I mean ABSOLUTELY, everywhere. Sometimes, when a character shows up in a fight, what they say may not even be what's displayed on screen (In particular, Frieza and Vegeta rarely know what they're saying.). That's not to mention the bits you find in the shopping menus and non-cutscene dialog. It gives a sense that the translation of this game was incredibly rushed. Like, 'get it done by lunch' rushed.  Lastly, and this is more of a personal grievance, though I know others share the sentiment, there are not beam struggles. That's a staple of Dragonball Z itself, as well as the better fighting games it has produced. There are still physical clashes, but I've yet to win one of those, as there's nothing that tells you how to do it. Button mash? I'd love for you to tell me which buttons. I've tried them all.  Now,,. the praise.  This game is the ♥♥♥♥. Everything that they did right, they did amazingly. The character creation is some of the best I've ever seen (Though I would have liked to be able to make an Android character, but that's neither here nor there.). Saiyan, Eartling, Namekian, Majin (every single one directly related to the big pink fatass, I might add.) and whatever the hell you call Frieza, there are almost endless combinations of parts and styles to choose from, every bit of which lets you pick what color you want for that specific part. Ever seen a blue and orange Namekian with a spikey skin mohawk and red eyes? You will.  The story mode is amazing. You'll see just about every important moment in DBZ history in addition to some completely new ones, AND get to fight alongside the regular cast. Who among you never got the urge to jump into Gohan's fight with Cell and deck the power-stealing sum♥♥♥♥♥ yourself? None of you.  There's tons of replayability, too. Every PQ has hidden objectives, and drop some amazing things, like famous characters clothing and moves.  You can learn from a master as you progress, all of them key heroes and villains, From Krillin to Beerus the Destroyer, and a lot of major names in between. Each of them will test your strength, and teach you their exclusive moves, which you can't get from any missions.  You can play online or off. When on, you can directly interact with other people roaming Tokitoki city. When off, a few handfuls of those same people will appear as non-interactive NPCs, so you can admire the cool ones or laugh at the silly ones without drawing their attention. I once saw a player character named Kim-Jong Uub. Enough said.  All in all, if you're a fan of fighting games, Dragonball Z, or both, you'll love this game. You'll buy this game. Dragon Ball finally hits Steam! But with Battle of Z and Ultimate Tenkaichi in mind,  is this an arrival we should celebrate? Dimps are no strangers to fighting games (They created Street Fighter IV's engine) so they should have what it takes to create a knock-out title.  It's not exactly the deepest fighter around and there are some absolute killer combinations of certain Z-souls, support abilities and Ultimates that completely break any balance Dimps may have been going for. Still, there is enough to the game to make experimenting entertaining both in terms of the combo mechanics, and in the different stuff you can attach to your character (Z-souls especially). The game's idea of difficulty is rather skewered though, as it would rather give enemies super armor, strength in numbers or give you a rock-stupid Ai partner that you have to keep alive in spite of its suicidal tendencies rather than simply making the enemies competent. There's also some stupid walls of RNG attached to getting good item drops even when you do score a perfect Ultimate Finish. But that's Dimps for ya.  You've no doubt noticed the MMO-ish aspects of the game. See, you have the option of choosing between single and multi lobbies. In multi, you can walk around and interact with other people in real time and fight against each other or team up on missions as you'd expect. However, single lobbies work rather differently as you don't actually interact with other people. instead, the game spawns other player avatars as NPCs.  A question many seems to be asking is 'is this always online?'. The answer is that it isn't, so long as the servers work correctly. Usually, if you can't establish a connection, the game simply tells you that the online multiplayer aspects aren't available and boots you into the single lobby where you can do all the single player stuff as usual. However, some people have experienced problems wherein the game will put you in an endless loop of trying to establish a connection that never allows the player to enter the single lobby. Others get into the lobby, but are sent back to the title screen every time they finish their missions.  If you do encounter these kinds of connectivity issues that hinder you from playing at all,  they can be temporarily fixed simply by booting Steam in offline mode.

Fun game. Love it. Would recommend. But positives have been covered many times, so what about the bad?  Smooth PC port, but not very well PC adapted.   Can't use mouse to navigate menus   Only FXAA   Returns you to the title screen when turning off FXAA and VSync.   The game has general usability problems. Character attributes are shown in numbers, while the attribute gains from equipment are shown in... arrows. Some people might get tired of running around the lobby to start the game mode they want, without having an quic launch option. Escpecially as some missions require you to run through multiple lobby areas.   The game isn't very pretty. It emulates the anime style well which looks good most of the time. But there has been some incredibly lazy texture work in parts of the lobby town. Given how small that area is and the time you'll spend there, I really think they could have put more effort into it. Apart from some lighting and shader effects, this game looks like it was made 6 years ago.  And how come they still can't make cutscenes without awkward pauses between the characters saying their lines? It's like they're all politely waiting for each other to finish talking or yelling.

So, first up, I'm gonna say that I have been a longtime fan of DBZ. Friends and I were watching it before it was even brought to america, we all sat and watched imports (complete with japanese commercials) and had fun guessing at what the people were saying. Krillin was called 'Dots' cause of the dots on his forehead. :P  Fast forward a decade or so and the dbz games under my belt are a few of the super famicom versions, both import and local 'dbz legends' and then Dragonball z budoki 3 with lite experience with a few others.  I am both pleased with and dissappointed with Dragonball Xenoverse and here's why: After 21.3hrs playtime, AFTER the server stability upgrades....  Positives: ++ A character creator that allows you to create your own dbz characters that is actually not too bad. Somewhat decent options with more customization to appearance unlocked via drops or purchases from the clothing shop in game (no, not a cash shop)  ++ Wide variety of powers you can find with even more powers that you can earn from story characters that you gain as 'Mentors' which include Captain Ginyu, Frieza or even Beeru, the war god.  +++ Lots of classic DBZ action  + Takahata of Team FourStar does the voice for 'Male voice 8' and there's even a TFS Nappa easter egg in game that is easy to find (just chat with the NPCs in Toki Town and listen to thier voice greetings)  Minuses: - UNBELIEVEABLY grindy! I spent at least 5-10 hours of game time grinding side quests in order to get certain powers or items and after fighting Frieza, the very next fight was Cell and Mr Satan. Mr Satan was actually a bit Difficult! Time to grind for a few hours more to build my lvls so the next story fight isn't such a chore.  -- Mentors are very ambiguous when it comes to what they expect you to do before advancing thier training.  -- While stated that the Character creator/customization isn't too bad, it still pails in comparison to ALOT of other character creators. For me, being a fashion wh***, this hurts. Alot of options leave something to be desired and there's currently NO WAY to color your powers. To truly make a character your own, I think it would have gone a long way to be able to color my own abilities, you know? Also, why can't I color the clothing options I buy? You give us the ability to color our starting 'no stat' clothing and you keep the options available throughout the game, but you don't allow us to color what we buy? Another point that doesn't make sense.  -- DODGE!! This is hard to do. Most of the times that I try a teleport, either the pc is anticipating where I'll be or I just blip out and reappear in the exact SAME spot. FORGET trying to make blocking useful.  - Small touches that could have made the game better: Eliminate 'cr*ppy dub syndrome' when the characters talk. Make terrain damage more dynamic and have it hang around longer than a second or two. Why can I NOT sit on the benches in Toki Town?? Why can I NOT actually CHAT on a multiplayer PC game? I get that it is a console port, but there's tons of console multiplayers that allow better communication! MAKE THE SCOUTER WORK LIKE THE GAME TELLS YOU IT SHOULD! Yes, it shows you the lvl of the character you're facing, but it's slow to turn on and off and you can't fight while using it. Also, contrary to what the scouter tutorial tells you, it does NOT show whether or not there are enemies waiting on the other side of that gate!  -- PVP battles don't seem to be balance matched to xp lvls at all and there is no way to gauge the other person's xp lvl or abilities until you actually fight them. I tried my hand at a few battles and in one case managed to land only a small amount of damage before being perma juggled and thrashed to defeat. The others were pretty much along the same lines. It was clear that I was fighting more powerful characters and would have been nice to know BEFOREHAND. Characters in DBZ were able to sense power lvls in advance...  --- THE SERVERS ARE -STILL- UNSTABLE!!! When I'm not getting the immediate message 'unable to connect to Xenoverse server, here, play it offline', I can only play a few battles at most before I'm kicked out.  6.5 / 10 Overall, I feel it is definitely a good game, but definitely could have been done way better. If you're a dbz fanboy/girl, you may get a good amount of enjoyment out of Xenoverse, but just keep in mind that this game is in no way, shape or form perfect. Would definitely recommend waiting snatch it on a sale.

2015, the year of Dragon Ball. Xenoverse just came out, and DB Extreme Butoden for 3DS (by Arc System Works!) and the new movie 'DB Revival F' are coming out this year in Japan. If you are a DB fan, you must be excited...unless, the game sucks. Good news! DB Xenoverse is an excellent game. I can see the developer really put a lot of effort into it. The fighting mechanic is fun, the story is interesting, and there are a good amount of character customization.   The fighting mechanic of XV is not complicated, but with evasive moves, and guard cancel & jump cancel combos, I find it very enjoyable, and it is more than enough for a DB fan fighting game. Not to mention, the fights resembles those of in the anime very well. (I especially love the smooth SSJ transformation.) The game may seem unfair to some in the beginning, but once you get the fighting mechanic and invested a bit of time in building character and customize skill, it shouldn't be hard. It is always fun to test out new kills when you just get them anyway. There is a bit of grinding to do to get the gears and skills you wanted, but it's not half as bad as Monster Hunter (MH is one of my fav by the way).  The story of XV starts a bit slow, but after Mira and Towa(instant fan!) show up, the pace picks up. And the final battle, it's so cool and satisfying. This game had a lot going for it, but ultimately cannot be recommended.  First, the good: The three-dimentional combat works remarkably well. The battles are generally fast-paced, and the ultra-moves are spectacular. The time-traveling setup provides an effective and interesting framing-device, and the resulting list of missions allow for a wide variety of scenarios. Fight alongside your favorite characters from DBZ... or change history by standing alongside the villains and securing THEIR victory. Lots of spectacular optional battles where heroes or villains from across the continuum join forces, too. Care to fight Super Vegeta 2, 100% Final Form Frieza and Powered Perfect Form Cell all at once? The game will provide you the opportunity to do that and more. Huge selection of fighters, including characters from outside the normal canon (Bardock, Broly, and several from DBGT, just for starters) and with it comes an equally huge selection of super-moves and ultimate moves, for all your ki-beam-throwing needs. The ability to create your own fighter and set him/her/it up just the way you like is as satisfying as promised - there's a huge variety of clothes and accessories to go with your carefully-configured character-appearance. Be a hulking titan, or a pint-sized powerhouse! Anything goes.  ......BUT! And this is, as Zero Punctuation's Yahtzee would put it, a big, STINKY but. For all its advantages, it's got greater disadvantages. The combat works well... but you have to choose between 'interesting' and 'possible'. Meele combat is fast-paced and fun, but the useful skills are few and far between, and high-level enemies will devastate you without trouble, since they basically don't flinch - making them impossible to combo. Ranged combat (using 'Ki blasts') is extremely potent, but quickly gets really, really dull. Stand back while your allies distract the enemy, fire your favorite flavor of multicolored death at them (knocking off large chunks of the enemy's health-bar), then charge up your Ki again. Rinse and repeat until all enemies have fallen. That's it. That's ALL you're going to be doing for the last half of the game - well, that or constantly dying. Meanwhile, the huge roster of fighters has some glaring, obvious holes in it. Several familiar faces are missing, including Androids 16, 19 and 20. Intermediary forms of Frieza are missing, as is Cell's non-Perfected form.   And of course, there's the servers - the game has aspirations of MMO-ness, and while it CAN work just fine offline, it will stubbornly TRY to connect to the servers, often failing miserably and wasting your time in the process. If you DO connect, expect to get kicked off time and time again, returning to the main menu every time. Lose your internet-connection in mid-battle? The game will likely crash, taking your progress with it. This issue will probably be aleviated over time, as the dwindling number of players eases the pressure on the servers... also reducing the POINT of the multiplayer.  Several other niggling details tear away at the enjoyment. Randomness rules the day - enemies and allies alike may randomly drop pieces of gear or skills while you fight, and if you're trying to get your hands on a particular skill (either because it's awesome or because it suits your character perfectly), it can take a LOT of grinding to actually get it. Worse, the 'Ultimate Success' of side-missions is random too. To expand: Fulfilling certain requirements during missions (such as winning under a time-limit, keeping escort-targets from taking too much damage, or defeating enemies in a particular order) will activate 'Ultimate Success', providing an extension for the mission where new enemies appear, old ones ressurect and power up, or other interesting events occur... if you're lucky. If you're not, you can play the same mission over and over a dozen times, fulfilling the requirements each and every time, and still never see the special ending. Several of the missions are also frustratingly difficult to the point of impossibility, and while being ganged up on by constantly beam-spamming Super Saiyans can be handled with the right set of skills and a maxed-level character, there's no counter for escort-targets who can be one-shotted by the final enemy and constantly bounce right up in said enemy's face.  So no, I would not recommend buying it. In the final tally, it's got more frustrations than awesomeness. That being said, if you DO buy it, make sure to play it through to the end. The final, post-game chapter is ALMOST epic enough to make up for all the annoyance that went before. Almost.

The Dragon Ball Z timeline has changed, things have been distorted, important moments are being twisted and everyone is being killed off at the wrong moment by the hands of villians who have somehow powered up and gotten even more cruel. Suddenly, a mysterious hero taking a blur of many shapes, sizes, forms, races, and powers, jumps out from time and space to help out the heroes and set things straight once again. But, what is this crazy new evil power the villians are utilizing? Who is this strange hero who's always there to even out the fight to restore the timeline? Find out... By playing DRAGON BALL XENOVERSE!   Ahem... Sorry, I had to get that out of my system first. Anyway... Welcome to Parallel universe theory where you can do lots of crazy things and have it still 'make sense'... Vaguely.  Ever wanted to be in Dragon Ball Z and kick some butts and take some names?  Ever wanted a big community hub in a DBZ game with lots of players wandering around with self made characters and easily accessed Multiplayer that includes both Co-op quest missions AND PvP with 1v1, 2v2, and 3v3?  Ever wanted to do all the DBZ poses together with friends that doesn't involve any cosplay or going to a con and have it be admired and applauded by a bunch of random people?  Ever wanted to create the mystical rarely ever seen Saiyan and Majin Females to run around and look fabulous?  Ever wanted to just roll with the villians and kick the heroes in their butts so hard they spin flip into next tuesday?  Ever just, wanted to see a a group of 3 Yamchas somehow take down all the main villians? Or, you know, turn it around and have Frieza, Cell, and Buu all at once pummel Yamcha into a corpse a hundred times over?  If any of that sounds appealing at all you'll want this game. ------------------------------------------------------------------- However, there is a slight split over opinion on this game. This part is where I'll discuss the actual gameplay and go a little more in-depth on the status of the PC Port. Read on if you want the little details, but be warned, I'M TYPING UP A STORM!  First off, this is not a pure blood DBZ fighting game, it won't handle like any of the Budokais or Tenkaichis. So if you REALLY want combat like a true fighting game and would hate it if it was anything else, please save your money and other players the hassle of having to deal with more of the same complaints. You'll feel that the combat is way too 'clunky' for your tastes.  Now, with that aside...  This game has RPG elements, to mix in with the fighting, so it essentially becomes a Hybrid. You'll have basic fight game systems in place, simple combo strings, for example, Weak Attack x5 -> Strong Attack x3 or Weak Attack x4 -> Strong Attack x2, and such. 'Super' Skills are all mapped to 4 buttons after holding down a trigger on controllers or pressing another button first on Keyboard and Mouse. They happen right away and can be thrown into your regular attack combos if you're savvy enough and good at timing them. There's another 4 skills that get mapped however, three of them are 'Ultimates' which take three times as much energy as regular super skills but dish out a lot more damage and give you super armor during the entire duration (can be useful but also detrimental depending on what the opponents do) and the last one is an 'Escape' skill that lets you get out of combos instantly, usually causing a counter attack effect that deals a bit of damage back to your attacker. (No DBZ Sagas combo looping here!) If you panic and forget to use the escape skill or just don't want to bother, you can also hit the jump/ascend button to do a small teleport that nets you some invincibility frames and usually gets you at least to the side of the enemy if not behind them to catch them off guard and start your own combo. This method is more risky due to the fact that sometimes it doesn't work out as planned and you'll start getting hit again regardless. The RPG elements are simple too, there's a simple gathering and crafting system, and a rudamentary leveling up system where you gain 3 stat points with every level up and can spend them to increase your stats such as your HP, Ki Pool, Stamina Pool, and different attack stats. This allows for some basic character specialization into either a pure up close fighting, a pure Ki Blast user, or a hybrid of both to do mix ups. If you're just going to do missions and such with friends, how you specialize your damage won't matter TOO much as they can be boosted with the help of gear you gain access to as random loot drops from beating quest missions or buying from the shops when they unlock as you progress through the story.  If you're a fan of this Hybrid Fighting RPG gameplay that's found in some other games like Final Fantasy Dissidia or Phantasy Star Online, then you'll feel right at home with this game.  Now, gameplay aside, lets take a look at the port. At first, I went into it with low expectations, I mean, it's Namco Bandai, did you SEE their Dark Souls Port? It was so awful the community fixed it for them by making mods.  This however... Ohoho, this game... It's port? Let me just say that it's pretty astounding, at least compared to what I've seen from them before.  It's nailed the basic PC options menu pretty well, the resolution can go up to your monitor's max, you can turn Vsync on or off, There is however, no option to fiddle with the graphic options directly, but the game does auto detect your PC's specs and turns things to suit them the best while keeping things looking amazing. There is ONE option that you can change but it might cause slow down on older PCs, it's their shading system. I can't tell if it's because the shadows are super well done to make everything look nice and Manga/Anime-y or if it's because they couldn't find the time to optimize it correctly but fiddling with the Shadows option is usually enough to boost performance. There is also a frame counter option, but it goes roughly between 50 and 60 depending on your resolution, which is better than consoles mind you as they're locked at 30 FPS. You can of course go into the files and un-limit your frames if your monitor and PC can handle it.  Now with the options out of the way, lets see how well optimized this game is.  I have a higher end system so I should be able to run it without too much problems right? Well, yeah, except it's running so smoothly it's like watching butter melt down over a hot plate of pancakes. So I went around and asked people with lower systems. A couple of people got the 'minimum requirements' on Can I Run It and they get the same smoothness as long as they fiddle with the options a bit... So I can safely say, this game is pretty well optimized, if not amazingly so. This can also be in part to how simple most textures in the game are, while this might make other Triple A titles look appalling, the cell shaded textures fit the DBZ style so well that with the more simple textures it actually makes the game look even better. Most of the detail is on character models but even then they don't have things like tiny little details you can only see if you have hawk eyes or a microscope.  I kind of lost my train of thought here so, I can say one thing for certain... This game is a great RPG Fighting Hybrid, it's got a sense of community thanks to the hub, it can run on pretty much any system due to how well made it is, the PC controls don't suck, and DBZ fans get to live out their fantasies.  Just don't go into it expecting the Budokais and the Tenkaichis.

I have played both intensively and casually every DBZ game from the PS1 editions to the GBA sprite versions to the popular budokai 3. I will make things detailed for each section for everyone looking to buy this game and/or get the season pass.    Gameplay   8/10, as others have mentioned the game has a lot of skills and abilities for you to use from basically the whole series to its own unique versions, the grind in the game is actually a positive part of the game as it adds things for you to do HOWEVER there are some things I don't agree with. For example, You  could  get Super Saiyan early by beating a 3 star mission or you can spend those same hours grinding to just unlock it in the shop. It would be fine if it wasn't for the fact that it's really hard to get the skill and the time spent grinding for it could just be spent getting to the point in the story where you can simply buy it. None the less I still helped my friend grind for it as there is a sense of accomplishment but strategically it's better to wait it out. The game offers quite a few ways for you to play your character but there are certain moves that are just outright unfair and unblockable, it's not as big of an issue since it's a new game and balancing still needs to occur but it is significant enough in the story mode to lower the rating. Additionally another problem which made this a solid 8 rather than when I originally wanted to 10/10 gameplay is that auto attacks are very simplistic and lack depth which is apparent since there is only a single page for when you open up the combo list, teleporting behind/infront of characters costs way too much even though I find teleporting is a significant part of fighting in almost all games and it is showcased a lot in the anime series.     Story   10/10 As a Dragon Ball Z fan, the story gets real old with every retelling and you basically know what to expect, they have done a great job making the story engaging and making your character feel like they are genuinely interacting with the story and making things better. This becomes even more apparent as when you beat missions the city populates with new faces which creates a sense of accomplishment. After I had finished the story, I wanted more as it was engaging and while I haven't finished the story 100% (at 90% currently), I am happy to see there is more to come in the DLC packs. What makes the story engaging is as the other users have mentioned, the creators did a great job of answering popular fan questions of 'what if goku failed', it lacked depth at times beyond 'time and history will fall apart' but it is a great idea and it was well executed, sometimes even featuring what happens because goku failed. While you can't expect a whole new rendition of the story line, the game does a great job of telling the original story as well as adding its own twists, coming out of the game I could explain most of the DBZ story to another user without actually seeing the anime. While at the same time, knowing the potentials if one of the key characters had failed/succeeded.    Pricing   10/10  The bundle pack is easily justifiable for anyone who is a fan of the series, I've paid more for other games such as CoD which turned out to be a bundle of sticks. This game goes above and beyond for delivery and while so far you can get the same content by getting the cheaper version, I highly suggest getting the season pass for that glorious DLC and besides that, you are supporting the developers which will help push out content faster as well as attract some big players to bring DBZ to the PC and hopefully even start pumping out an xenoverse sequel or to add more content to the game and features.    Customization   6.5/10 Initially the customization is great as you are given quite a few choices and thematically the characters all make sense, I can tell apart a Saiyan from a human and overall the team has done a great job to allow the users to be able to customize. Unfortunately as certain clothes prove to be better for your characters build, you find yourself wearing the same outfit as others who have the same build as you, the more you venture into the game, the more you find yourself noticing close clones. I was under the assumption you could change the color of ANY item which would greatly expand the small clothing selection but was quickly let down when realizing that is not the case. Additionally, the game almost taunts you with the amount of races that you cannot pick or for certain characters you cannot play as, for example Buldos race or being able to play as the dark version of Frieza. The game has quite a few choices for character creation especially as a at launch game which is great and from the DLC packs it is easy to tell that more options will soon be available. As for new races, unfortunately I do not think they will be implementing anything beyond the 5 choices.    Graphics   9/10 Overall there isn't much to say about the graphics, it's sharp clean, and looks amazing in ALL available market resolutions, I have a 4K monitor and it was just beautiful to watch, the cutscenes were equally as beautiful. The games bright colors has an eye candy effect and even in dark rooms you can clearly see where is what, what made the graphics tank is the fact that the game is still glitchy with cloth effects such as hair moving/tail coats moving as well as the lip syncing is a bit silly. The game needs some polish but it turned out pretty damn well for an initial launch.    Cons   4/10  Keyboard controls are atrocious, using a controller is basically mandatory and I find myself wishing some keys would be mapped together such as instead of having two separate keys for supers and ultimates, to have a toggle instead with ctrl would make the keys more accessible, remapping the keys before playing is highly recommended. On both controller and keyboard, throwing is really easy to forget for key combination and every single one of my friends who I told to get the game still had no idea how to throw even after being told how ingame. The game seems to lack some hindsight and QA testing which leads to overpowered abilities, bad mapping of controls, and other issues which really makes the overall score tank. The game basically screams for a chat system as I find myself seeing players spam 'hello', additionally it needs more sectors/cities, the current city is over crowded and with so many clients requesting to see other players, it's no wonder why the servers are having issues, the game just wasn't made in mind for a huge player base such as what we have now and because of the lack of foresight, a lot of players including myself find ourselves playing offline and for online mode to just invite friends in a created lobby. Other issues include the chat system its self being very annoying and requires a mute button, I seriously wish I could play main story quests with friends which is a let down seeing as some quests are very very hard. The game also screams for a friends list, inviting friends to a lobby is tedious as you have to switch from controller to mouse just to invite them using the steam interface, an friends list in game would solve this issue and would keep friends in an easy glance to read. The game also screams for clans/guilds which it lacks as well as a trading system. The fact that you can have multiples of the same clothing but not be able to trade seems like a design flaw.  Another issue I found was that the game lacked any sort of height depth, with all the graphics way at the top of the screen, as well as it being a dragon ball Z game, the first initial thing I tried while in town was to fly, which I was presented with just a jump instead, the jump its self is useless as all the things that you could be able to pass is blocked by an invisible wall.    Overall   7.9/10, great game. get it, a fresh take on both mmorpg and fighters.

It's good, but it could have been great. The game makes zero effort to introduce the characters so unless you are already a fan of the show you will more than likely be a little lost and the story will just be flashes of characters you don't know. It is still a fun game though. If the combat wasn't as much fun as it is the item grinding would kill this game. It's totally random and gets very frustrating.  There's a lot of little things that are starting to really bug me. Stuff that either shows they were rushed near the end or they starting putting less effort in. Spelling mistakes in the dialog (Beersu instead of Beerus is the last one I noticed. There have been many. Trunk',s with a comma and an apostrophe was another), either sounds are missing from certian parts or they were never added when they should have been (Vegeta transforms in silence during his training missions. Every time. It just looks silly.), the battle music fades in and out at seeminly random times (I've been mid combo when all of the sudden the music was gone and replaced, only for about 3 seconds, with the exploration music and then abruplty back to battle music), TokiToki City theme is really short and the repeating over and over gets annoying (And it reminds me of Chumbawamba's Tubthumping and there is no excuse for that), characters have about 2 lines they repeat over and over during battle no matter how far into the story you are (Piccolo: 'Where's that power coming from?! *10 seconds later* Where's that power coming from?! *start to power up* 'Where's that power coming from?!) but the grinding is honestly the worst part. It's totally random no matter what rank you get and there is no sense of reward or rarity of items becuase you have the same chance of getting Krillin's baseball cap as you do Super Saiyan 2 or a Dragon Ball. It's kind of funny that the grinding that everyone seems to be praising as giving so much replay value is the one thing that will keep me from ever starting over. If I had to unlock everything for every new character I made there is no way I would ever have more than 1 character. There is JUST enough fun in the battle system to keep me coming back to play. Don't buy this if you're looking for a brawler with RPG elements becuase you will be frustrated and dissappointed. Buy this because it is the best Dragon Ball game so far....and if it's on sale.   6.5/10

One of the best Dragon Ball Z games in recent memory, Xenoverse expands on the best feature of Ultimate Tenkaichi (and the only good feature, depending on who you talk to) by providing a character customization function and an original story to play through. As much as people who grew up watching the series may love it, you can only do the story so many times before it gets old. Xenoverse manages to spice up the experience by altering key events and giving you a new focal villain to deal with.  Those who are fans of the previous Dimps DBZ games such as the Budokai series will sadly feel a bit let down. While the gameplay is fun and can get very frantic, it embraces the 3D flying aspects of more recent games than the traditional 2D pure fighting game style that their games were praised for. If you are looking for a strict fighting game, Xenoverse is not that. It is a fun experience, but it is not what some people were looking for.  Now that the server issues cleared up from launch, the game runs solidly, though I have experienced server hiccups still. Sometimes in-game connections can get spotty, and I have had a few missions end up with everyone swinging at an invincible Krillin as the server struggles to realign everyone. Despite this, I still recommend it to anyone who enjoys the series and wants a fun time making their notebook OCs into a reality.

Hey everyone, really quick here is my personal review. Total: 7.6 (Not Bad, could use some improvement though) Graphics: 7 Mechanics: 6 Story: 8 Controls: 8 Gameplay: 8  Graphics - 7  Not my favourite thing, the graphics to Xenoverse are not super appealing. The corners are a bit jagged, and I think a little more anti-aliasing and a bit less contrast would be useful, just to cut back on eye strain.  Otherwise, it is definitely Dragonball, and feels like it.   Mechanics - 6  I've heard and seen a lot of complaints about characters being too fast to hit and hit boxes not functioning. Enemies can be a pain when they are faster if you don't have a higher level. Also, some CPUs are inherently stupid and just fly in circles fast enough you can't hit them with any form of aimable attack.  However, the game does offer plenty in the realm of unique attacks, each with different mechanics to make it more or less useful to use for your character. The amount of coding to go into these moves is impressive, even more when animations are accounted for.  Story - 8  Very easily the best Dragonball Game story I've seen, period. It didn't just use Dragonball's story as a backdrop to a fighting game, it adapted the game to the story. Every detail from Character Building, to the stages, to the XP system worked for the purpose of story progression. A unique story in the future is by far what I'd enjoy.  The Post-Story is the one thing keeping me from putting this higher. I dislike that Broly, a character only about as strong as Cell and weaker than Buu, ended up being the final boss after beating both Beerus and Demigra, both Gods.  Controls - 8  I'm sad to say my biggest disapointment here is that there is no run ability in Toki Toki City. Being able to run (Or Fly) would make travel in the area so much more convienent. Otherwise you have to walk at the slow speed to the stores or Parallel Quests before rejoining the main story. Otherwise controls run fairly smooth.  Gameplay - 8  Between the story and other options, Custom Characters and moves work out very well as a reason to be drawn to the game. The Mentor system makes me happy, as it highlights and mirrors Goku's own training throughout the series. The Parallel Quests even explain a big chunk of the story, explaining why they exist is to halt the Butterfly effect from occuring due to the changes made by your very presence at events.  The big, crippling injury to Gameplay is the low drop rate of skills from Parallel Quests. You can spend hours working on farming a skill and not get it. In some cases it comes in a run or two, others it can take hundreds.  However, the game starts by throwing you right into the story, with the massive battles starting between Goku, Freiza, Cell, and Kid Buu. This gives you time to test the controls out for yourself a bit before the actual tutorial, a battle against Future Trunks, takes place.  My Favourite Things, In Order: - Character Customization - Thrown right into action - Each move is different - No Character Clones - Voice 8 Easter Egg  My Least Favourite Things, Why, and How to Fix Them: - Male and Female characters within the same species have different stats. This annoys me, because it makes playing a Female Strike Character not so valuable, because her stats will be lower. Similarly (Though not usually what I dealt with) Male Ki characters were also not as strong. Removing this system would be good for all involved, as it hinders character customization to build off gender stereotypes. Plus with Majin, it allows a more Kid-Buu like character to be made. - 'Ki Spamming.' Super and Ultimate Moves don't have a cool-down between use to increase variation. Some have a set-up, but others such as Ill Flash or Symphonic Destruction start almost immediately making it hard to dodge. While I understand Ki Spammers usually get killed by someone knowing how to work around the move, it is probably better in the future to add a brief cooldown to make it more effective to vary a moveset in a DPS way. - Characters. I know this is going to be a sticky subject, but there are very few story characters to play as of various races. Namekians only have one, Piccolo, and the Frieza Clan has one (technically 3) in Frieza. Buu's three forms are present, as the only Majin as well. While I understand the story limitations, these characters were included, plus a slightly different model between full power and standard Cell, and Goku and SSG Goku. I feel the memory that one of the two Cells, the Freiza Henchmen, or the Saibamen used could have been better utilized to add King Cold or Dende/Slug. Given a new series is on the way, the next installment in the Series could better use those spaces for new characters from Dragonball Super, however. I'd reccomend going through the characters most commonly used in Online Mode, and Online Battles, on top of just Polling for which of the show/movie characters people like the most and figuring out which should be added to the Game. I ensure you, nobody will miss Appule, Saibamen, or Cell Jr. in the Character Selection screen. - 'Grinding' Grinding for skills is obnoxious in this game, with the Random Number Game making it hard to get some of the most desired items and skills. I think it might be more effective to have the Randomized drops take into account average score (per player) compared to current score per mission, and number of games to help determine if a skill drops from a Quest. Otherwise, adding more to the Skill Shop would be helpful! - No Transformations. Aside from Super Saiyan, only Kaioken exists for Transformation Skills. It could find better use to add other Transformation skills to other races, especially Freiza Clan members or Majin. Adding a better regenerative ability to Namekians (Drain Stamina for Health, maybe?) and Humans (Drain Health for Ki and Stamina) could replace the existing transformations and make sense within the story.  Overall this was a good game, and if another like it is made I will pick it up! However, in it's current state it will really only appeal to people who are big fans of Dragonball, and not just people who like games. This is something that time and tweaking could change.

I may have preferred Dragonball over DragonballZ or its predecesors and I may not have kept up with them either, however I enjoyed this game. While it doesn't offer very unique story (from what I understand it's mostly drawn from the tv show,) it does offer a very satisfying gameplay. Unlike most fighting games it focuses on knowing when to use an ability or combo as opposed to how quickly you can press a series of buttons. (Pressing R Trigger + button for supers and pressing L+R Triggers for ultimate attacks, combos use X & Y, some other side things like grab or basic ki blast all in a simple easy to use package.)  To those who are perhaps not so good at fighting games that have high demand for perfect combo sequences like myself, Dragonball Xenoverse is an excellent fighting game that you might enjoy more fully. As for those who like a competitive play worry not, while simple in controls it's still about timing and strategy and I encourage the experienced fighting game players to give it a try as well.

The combos don't always chain, and when they do, they tend to knock the opponent out of the chain. This is especially true with the most simple 'hold down the ki attack button to rapid fire' combo. The game would have been far better and well worth the money then.

Alright, let me clear something up. I do like this game. I think it can be fun at times. Unfortunatly, those times have HUGE time gaps. Let me list the things I like and the things that I don't. Pros: -character customization (pretty darn cool) -move list (pretty darn big) -fights (sometimes pretty intense) Cons: -character customization (can only make a second character AFTER beating the game, which is dumb) -move list (made up mostly of ki blasts, is lacking in any awesome strike specials, and there are few transformations to pick from, going from kaioken as a human, to super saiyan as saiyan. pretty sure thats all you can do.) -fights (often times are really boring and can be exploited easily, or are mind-bogglingly hard. Also there are mechanics that I still haven't figured out yet (like the fist-clashy-thingie).) -boss fights (two words you will grow to hate: SUPER ARMOR) -clothing (you can't preview the clothes that you buy, and you only get half of the money you pay for selling it, so you better hope that you choose wisely.) -Multiplayer parallel quests( Don't bother. There are never any lobbies and it takes a billion years for anyone to join you.) -Beam clashes (remember those cool beam clashes from games like dbz budokai tenkaichi 3? Yeah. None of those here.) -Cool strike supers (remember stardust breaker or final revenger from budokai tenkaichi 3? Yeah. None of those here.) Aaaaaaand...yeah. I think that's about it. Oh, wait, I forgot a big one. - Super repetetive (This game starts out being fun. It really does. Then you start to realize that you really aren't changing the formula for the fights at all. Everything is about the same.) So yeah. It starts off being good, but it gets really boring over time. Don't waste your money on it, of on the dlc (DONT EVEN GET ME STARTED).

Xenoverse is a fun title for fans of the DBZ series. The best DBZ game since Budokai 3/Budokai Tenkaichi 3.  Pros:  -Plays like a mix between Budokai 3/Tenkaichi 3 -Great PC port -CaC is great, allows more than a few options -Includes all major sagas, plus Battle of Gods and a secret saga -Has Takahata101's Ghost Nappa as a vocie for your character -Tough but fair (for the most part) -Heaps of moves from all parts of the DB universe -Nice original story  Cons:  -Some important characters/transformations are missing (2nd/3rd form Frieza, Imperfect/Perfect Cell, Super Buu's absorptions, etc.) -While the voice acting is good, it's not synced up that well to the lip movements -Some of the anime cutscenes have a big sound desync (at least when I was playing through the story, might have been patched) -Parallel quest rewards are randomised, so it's a bit grindy if you want a particular move/piece of equipment -With at least the first DLC pack, it's a bit lackluster.  All in all, I'd recommend this immediately to anyone who enjoyed the Budokai/Tenkaichi series, or is just a fan of DB in general. Anyone else, it's a little bit of a hard sell at full price, so try it out at a friend's place or wait for a sale.
