I played Dragon Ball Tenkaichi for a long time, and really loved it. When Raging Blast came out, it was very different, and it actually managed to upset me. It may have been that I just never understood it, but it felt so much more like aimlessly mashing buttons, and like whoever moved first, got to go crazy. Dragon Ball Xenoverse, to me, is a return to the need for skill over speed. Yes, people will spam their ultimates and supers. But in this game, there's ways around everything.   Now, if you get caught between Super Saiyan Gohan's super kamehameha spam and Super Saiyan Goku's super kamehameha spam, you WILL die. So just a piece of advice, for way down the line: When you reach that point, just keep both of them in front of you, casually sidestep their ultimates, and just spam those tiny little ki blasts.   You'll also suffer greatly during the infamous 'stealth' mission, once you get to that point. I won't spoil why it sucks, but just know that you need to take the time to Z rank everything, including the parallel quests, up until you reach that particular mission. It will be a pain, but you will need the levels you get.   Aside from that... This is more like Tenkaichi than Raging Blast, but with custom characters, and a stamina bar replacing the little blue meter. If you liked Tenkaichi, consider getting this one. Also, the story is different, but ah, spoilers. ^_~

I recommend this game, yes.  Why? Well, it's because it's the best dbz game in history.... albeit also the ONLY good dbz game in history...  *alert potential spoilers, you have been warned*  At any rate, here are the cons of the game:  Vast amount of blast supers and ultimates, but in the strike department, this game is seriously lacking, there's one crucial one, and the rest are mostly just... meh... Being a strike based build is a waste of time, especially when blast supers and ultimates are easier to hit with.  PvP is literally dead already. Why? It's because the sayjan race can have unlimited ki attacks, until their ki runs out. so they can just spam their ultimates at you. And if they pair it with that strike skill I spoke of earlier, they also have unlimited ki. Go figure. Now add in a spice of super armour (no stagger occours) when equipping certain z-souls... Yes, who would play against that? it's basically a legal cheat.  Character customization, while being a bliss in just being there. Is fairly limited. You need to wield clothes that gives stat increases or decreases, so that they fit your playing style, which means you'll end up with one outfit you like best, and then never try anything else on. Oh, and you can't change colours on all clothing. There are a few races missing. from the dragon ball lore. Nothing that is quite impressive in the series, but even so, they are still lacking. Can't think of one in particular, but that is mostly because I don't know what they are called. And no... As a sayjan, you cannot go ape  Here's one thing though: You can't do squat about your basic attack patterns, if you want something different, you need to change class and/or gender. (yes, genders have different attack patterns) I get the idea, but it annoys me, since I love the grapple on the female sayjan, but hate it on the female majin, which is currently my main.  Oh, and grinding, there's also grinding, and let's not forget about grinding. Did I mention grinding? Yes, there is ALOT of grinding. Drops are random, and NOT guaranteed to drop in the first place. you'll spend tons of time going through the same quests to get that specific skill, or clothing piece. and there aren't that many quests to do. all of them are the same, safe for 2. where you will ''search'' for dragon balls.  And by search, I mean look at a dragon radar, land near the ball, and pick it up. Coulda been done better, but it's nice change.  The main hub?... god that wasn't the best idea, jumping is pointless, and you can't even take off... Waste of time. It'd been better with a menu. On the other hand, this would remove some immersion. But it could have been done better. alot better.  Anything else that bothers me about this game? Let's see here... In the all the quests, you'll often face multiple enemies at once, who are experts at stun juggle attacks, also ultimate spamming sayjans, and alot of super armour.  Good thing you can bring 2 npc's along XD (even if they are just there to be obstacles for the enemy)  Now then, the money system is also pretty pointless. Once you have everything you need from the stores, money is overrated. the only thing you'll be spending it on, is health capsules (healing pots) and the like. Which are rather cheap, once you start accumulating money in the millions.  Oh, and the chat, is limited to commands. there's no free chat. BORING.   Now then, what's the good stuff? the ''nitty gritty'' of it?  Lemme tell you;  The story mode. It is EPIC. you will not only visit the different eras in dbz lore, you will face it altered, trying to correct it! See, in the very first story, you'll face a raditz, who is stronger than the old radditz you know. So strong in fact, he broke free of gokus grapple, and survives, while goku still died. Bummer. You're sent head first into battle, and save his behind before that happens.  And before you know it, you'll be taking on titans in dbz lore.  The level system is well thought through, though the current max level is a bit of a weird thing... How many games has the max level as 99? Seriously, couldn't they go that one number higher?. It wouldn't mean much, but 99? At any rate, you can invest points in several areas, including max health, stamina and ki, as well as the power of your basic attacks, strike supers, and blast supers.  Invest the points wisely, you can't redo them without gathering all 7 dragon balls and wishing for a redo, which brings me to the next point: The dragon balls.  You obtain these by fighting other time patrollers during your quests (Not human fighters, rather an npc version of them) And then you have a chance to get a dragon ball. Once you have them all, you can make a wish, yay. Do so carefully though, as the wishes aren't as straightforward as one would think. but there are things you can only get this way.  Now then, what else is nice? The master system. You can gain a master, which is one of the characters from dbz lore, and they will teach you their skills. Pretty handy. You will get some of the best ultimates this way. Also, after a quest, they may give you an item. Sometimes, during battle, if you are struggling. They will come to your aid! alright... Vegeta versus vegeta, this is gonna be intere-wait what?!  Also, character customisation. I know it's not much, but it's the only dbz game that actually does exactly what everyone wanted. A game where YOU could create YOUR own character, and toss them into the world of dbz.  Now, if only they could have done better with the main hub... ah well, I guess there's always next time. Here's hoping for a xenoverse 2! (the ending certainly delivers a chance for a sequel, at least the vanilla ending. I have not played any DLC yet)   Now, do the cons outwheigh the pros?  Let's talk about price.... This game, is a whopping 50 euroes on steam. Not a small amount. and no. Don't buy it for that price, wait for it to be on sale, then buy it.  It's not worth it's price, but it's pretty damn close to being so. If only the main hub, and multiplayer aspect had been better. Perhaps an overworld like a traditional open world mmorpg.  But I guess we can't have the cake AND eat it this time, huh?  Well. In any event, thanks for sitting through this lengthy wall of text, hope it gave you some insight in terms of buying or not. Remember; even though this game has it's faults, I love it. why? Because it's the only GOOD dragon ball z game in the world. and it's not just the best of the worst. Nope. This game makes the others look like badly made flash games.

DRAGON BALL Z XENOVERSE  There is loads of Dragon Ball titles on the market, but none have surpassed like this master piece, Bandai Namco Games has released Dragon Ball Xenoverse and what a cracker it is, The story goes on these lines “An unknown force is changing history by altering key moments in the Dragon Ball timeline, prompting Future Trunks to summon a powerful warrior to come to his aid using the Dragon Balls.” I think this gives a game for hard-core Dragon Ball fans as it has elements of old story lines but getting altered is a way, as the plot is basically just a framing device to allow players to insert themselves into the timeline as a Time patroller, starting from the Saiyan Saga up to Buu like normal Dragon Ball Z game but they even included the Battle of Gods that was a really nice touch and a new GT story line DLC so you can kick baby’s ♥♥♥ and so on.  From the time-travel element, the battles are different enough from the original series it felt like it is really fresh and a new experience as a whole, creating some great scenarios in the storyline that actually makes me feel as though I am having an impact in the game, rather than playing the part of passenger on a sightseeing tour of my favourite scenes. I love the fighting mechanics with the Ki gauge is used for skills as normal and a stamina gauge for dashing and teleporting so you don’t get hit as much or just getting the ♥♥♥♥ out of town while a big ♥♥♥ Ki beam coming up yo ♥♥♥, which is a GREAT improvement from other DBZ games. The overall gameplay style is similar to that of the Dragon Ball Z: Battle of Z that I had on the PS3 and played for a long time.  It’s also possible to fly at high speeds around the large, free-roam maps to find materials such as different types of capsules to make items for boosts or hp gain. At times I have my falling outs with the game with some quests (Bardock I’m a Melee player) ;P but that’s normal right? It’s a nice challenging full blown game with a drop in drop out elements with it too that I like. I'm not a fighting game person by any means, but damn I love this game!  If you're a huge DBZ fan, this game was made with you in mind. Granted, I'm a little biased, but this game fits me just fine. The premise is that the past is being changed by Mira and Towa, and you've been summoned by Shenron to help Trunks and the Supreme Kai of Time change the past to be the events that actually happened. It's a different take from other DBZ games, where you're just re-enacting the story. The story in this game is solid, though, and while it does seem to start a little on the slow side, once it starts picking up, you'll want to see what happens next.  Other than the story, there is PvP and Parallel Quests. Parallel Quests are basically optional missions that you can partake in and receive unique skills, Z-souls, etc. which all help your character become more powerful. The only issue is you'll more than likely be grinding for what you want in the game. PvP can be either 1v1, 2v2, or 3v3, or you can have a unique Endless battle, where it is 1v1 with up to 4 spectators. The winner of the match fights the next person in line, and it keeps going from there.  Having a custom character in a DBZ game is incredible, A lot of people came up with some great characters, while parody characters are hilarious to look at (from Kaka-carrot-cake to the Pillsbury doughboy, I've seen a lot of unique characters).  There's not really much else to say about this game. If you're on the fence about it, I'd definitely get it. I purchased the Bundle Edition within the week it came out, and I have no regrets at all. Of course, if you're not a fan of DBZ, you may want to look at gameplay just to make sure it's your type of game. If you've played Dragon Ball games before, you're going to enjoy this one.

If you are sick and tired of reliving the same old sagas over and over again in other Dragonball games, then consider giving Xenoverse a try. The storylines have enough twists and 'what if' scenarios to make it feel fresh. Is it the best Dragonball game though? Not necessarily. The AI kind of sucks and the character roster is smaller than other DBZ games. The game also plays more like a situational MMO instead of a fighting game. You have a main hub, then you go to different stations to pick up and participate in quests to level up enough to take on the next bit of the story. I didn't find the MMO-like gameplay an issue, but for fans of the DBZ fighting games, this may take some getting used to.   Despite the flaws, there are many good aspects about Xenoverse. The character customizer is awesome and having your character be an integral part of the DBZ story is very rewarding and satisfying. The character roster, while limited, still contains some good characters with fun movesets to experiment with. The voice acting is amazing, with most of the show's actors reprising their roles. Finally, this game is riddled with fan service that fans of the show will definitely enjoy.  Here's what I would like to see: TEAMFOURSTAR DLC!!! If you don't know these guys, they edit and redub DBZ to get the story across but in a shorter amount of time and with funnier dialogue. They have done an amazing job adapting DBZ into their DBZ Abridged series, so I would love to see what they would do using the alternate universe storyline in this game! I think it would be hilarious, and the actors who work at TeamFourStar deserve a lot more credit than they get.  Overall rating: 7.1/10  Pros: +Character creator +Fresh story (written by Toriyama) +New villains +Voice Acting from original show +Lots of content to experiment with  Depending on the person: +/- MMO elements +/- Solid but bland combat +/- Server issues  Cons: -Grinding -Occasionally cheap bosses -Bland new characters

Starting out I want to go on record stating I love Xenoverse for what it is. Pass that I hate Xenoverse for what it gives.   The first problem you run into is the lack of online entertainment. What I mean by this is easy to explain. Have you ever taken a bite out of a chocolate chip cookie just to find out it’s raisin. Well that’s online Xenoverse. We were promised an online community where we could battles other players or cooperate with such players. We got more of a glitchy interface and a lack of player communication. This ideal drawing from the online battle system I ran into when I got the game. I asked for a ranked battle and waited and waited and waited until eventually two rooms popped up and the one I clicked ended up being full. After being thrown off of the screen I loaded the online battle a second time and waited and waited and waited until I got the room that was below the previous room. Remembering that I clicked ranked match, I got a match against an individual who was 30 levels above me. Long story short I lost. Pass the online battle we meet parallel quast. This system was better but not great. My first try with it ended with disappointment. There was a total of 3 rooms all of which were way above my skill set. After this I started a room for myself and waited and waited and waited until I got 2 other players and we started the quest. It felt very similar to fighting offline with little to no player cooperation or even communication.   So my conclusion to this game. Well not bad. The games online interface sucks and fighting with multiple Npc at a time while fun meets a frustrating mood once your teammate goes down. So why does Xenoverse rate so well? Simple Xenoverse doesn’t throw its failures down your throat allowing for a limited enjoyment. I’m hoping that Xenoverse is a stepping stone for future DBZ games and that dimps and bandai learn from its failures.

So I am gonna start this off by saying that I've been a watcher and an admirer of all things Dragon Ball for 15 years. Dragon Ball Z is my favorite show of all time and it's very sentimental to me since I watched it with my uncles a lot as kid and I still do to this day with Super and Kai. So you can rest well knowing this review is written by an almost lifelong fan of the series, or you can view it as biased, each to their own. This is probably the Dragon Ball game that is most true to it's source material since the Budokai games. It nails the art style, moves, fighting and characters down to a tee. The only thing I was disappointed with is no blast struggles. I would have loved to reenact the Kamehameha vs Galick Gun or struggle with a player online or a friend. The fighting is flawed but still fun in parts. The tracking can really suck resulting in wasted hits and special/ultimate attacks, you will experience a lot of missed attacks in this game. If you can cope with that like I do, that's great but there's no denying that it can be annoying. The story mode has you going through parts of all the indivisual arcs of the Z series (Saiyan, Namek, Frieza, Cell Game, Buu and unlockable Bardock and Broly stages). It's pretty enjoyable overall if you know what's going on, no severe grinding is required to match the skill of a certain opponent and it's all pretty quick compared to the parallel quests. The parallel quests serve as side missions where you can unlock attacks, z-souls, outfits and zeni (currency). These are just battle stages with some dialogue potentially pushed in. The difficulties of the quests are seperated. Completing these can be a task considering that you may have to grind due to the difficulty and time restrictions of some of the higher quests. It's not primary to play through these but it's there nonetheless. I personally found trainers to be a promising concept but it was executed in a pretty lack luster way. Trainers are there to teach you moves that they use in the actual story. For example, Vegeta will teach you the Galick Gun and Final Flash amongst others. The only way to progress in the training once you learn a move is grind in the campaign or parallel quests and get good grades. You could also use the most recent move they taught you in missions but I've found this to be optional. It can be a grind to make it through training and it's kind of disappointing how once they teach you that last ultimate, you kind of just move on to the next trainer. The leveling system is straight forward and what you'd expect a modern leveling system to be, gain EXP to level up. Once you reach level 80, this can begin to be a grindfest since you will rarely get above 60,000 EXP. So if you're planning to play this for a long time, keep that in mind. The online overall is really fun, if you can find someone who's playing it. You will more commonly find people playing online parallel quests than online battles, but in my experience online battle are a ton of fun, especially when you and your opponent are neck and neck and don't use items. Performance is not a problem, this game isn't costly to run which is good for a modern gen game. Although if you're playing on a casual laptop, don't be expecting to be playing at HD resolutions or high graphics. It's one of the better DBZ games I have played in recent times. I was a huge fan of the Budokai series on PS2 way back and I played some others like Budokai Tenkaichi 2 and 3 which were okay games but I perfered the classic fighting camera and the QTE's in the original Budokai games made it feel like the show when Tenkaichi did not.  The reason say this is because when I bought Xenoverse I wanted that Budokai feeling I had when I was a kid. A game where it felt like I was apart of the show or getting to see some dream fights I had as a kid. Budokai captured that for me but Xenoverse did not sadly.  I didn't like Xenoverse that much because of the pacing. Yeah, we've all seen the show in a million times in other games where Goku goes Super Sayian for the first time and you're like 'What the hell is happening' and when you realize its one of the best moments ever of DBZ. Suddenly, this just became your favorite show.  This game didn't capture that. It wasn't as epic as it should have been. Any of the big scenes in Xenoverse weren't even close to captured as the main show and it made the single player feel rushed. I would perfer if they just brought another games version of it over and recycle the voices lines instead of this.  Next is that I don't like they tried to make it like a MMO, without the tools that make a MMO. Its like they went half way. Oh you can see other players but you can't really interact with them. Maybe they did this because there might be kids purchasing the game and they don't want to have to deal with someone spamming the N word or something.  Lastly, the combat for this game is actually... pretty good. It felt polished so the gameplay was there and that is the only thing that made this game enjoyable and got me a good 25 hours of it before I stopped playing it. Only bad thing about the gameplay is online PvP is sometimes laggy and pot spamming and that makes the game unbalanced. Who thought that was a good idea?  Overall the game is okay. I'm mixed about it. If you're a DBZ fan I recommend it and if you've never heard of DBZ skip it. This game won't convince you to like the 90's show or get into that much at all because of how they tell the story of this game. If I wasn't a fan of DBZ I would of hated this game but it was fun for a little bit because I wanted to recapture my childhood again.  6.5/10  - Recommend for DBZ fans only.

A must have for any fan of the Budokai/Budokai Tenkaichi Games. Sagas are abridged, so not recommended as the first introduction to Dragonball. For fans of the series, there's plenty of nostalgia candy. Game design choices are hit-and-miss. Controller Support had no issues (plug-and-play Wired XBox 360 controller)  There's a good selection of playable characters along with different outfits (i.e. Saiyan Saga Vegeta, Goku Ginyu); however, skillsets are locked for the playable characters.  You can use practically every move from the series and some new ones (Yamcha's Saibamen death is even a move); however, some of the best skills require grinding and/or heavy RNG to acquire.  Grind can become an issue for desirable skills, outfits, and Z-Souls. Some items only drop when certain mission objectives are met, and even then they're not guaranteed to drop.  Clothes have stats, which would've been fine if they didn't also have trade offs (+2 to X, -2 to Y).  Really hurts making a perfect look & build combo.  In PvE, Saiyans are by far the superior race to cheese content due to Super Saiyan. During the Super Saiyan state, ki gradually decreases; however Supers and Ultimates consume no ki. Spamming AOE Ultimates remains highly effective throughout the game.  In PvP, it's a bit more diverse, although expect to deal with said Super Saiyan Spammers.   Couple ending notes regarding the Create-A-Character: You start the game with one character slot, eight in total. The other character slots are unlocked once you beat the main story. Your items and skills unlocked are shared across all characters, even if you delete your first character. The dragonballs can be used to reset your stats or appearance (can't change gender)   Overall, a great game for fans of the series, especially if you ever wanted to put yourself into the world of Dragonball. In terms of value, wait for a sale. The DLC (specifically Resurrection F) are a nice enhancement for endgame.  Also, some bundles (not the one in the Steam Store) do in fact still have the Pre-Order bonus (Gold/Crystal Battle Armor and Super Saiyan 4 Vegeta)

Prior to this game, my absolute favorite Dragon Ball game was Budokai 3 for the PS2 with Tenkaichi 3 being a close second. While both of those games are still incredible in my eyes, the fighting system in Xenoverse is hands down the most responsive and most importantly fun DBZ simulator I've ever played. Providing players with a new campaign that riffs on prior DBZ lore we all know and love is one thing, also giving the player an in depth character creator allowing you to make your custom z warrior is just icing on the cake. The combat system may seem simple on the surface, but their are layers of complexity waiting to be unearthed by those willing to invest the time into this unique fighter. All that said, the story is extremely repetetive and grind heavy with difficulty spikes that will test even the patient of indiviudals. These factors can easily disuade many from entry but I promise the payoff is whole heartedily worth the investment.
